comment_text:
Is CO2 Earth's Thermostat?  

Carbon dioxide has little or nothing to do with global warming. CO2 Is currently traced at 400 ppm. That is one carbon-dioxide molecule for every 2500 parts of the atmosphere. Humans contribute only a scant 16 ppm, which is 4% of the total CO2 accumulated in a year. CO2 only holds heat for a few seconds, and there is not enough of it to drive climate change. It is thermodynamically impossible! 
Also, bear in mind, that water vapor is the earth's most abundant and effective Greenhouse Gas. CO2 is only 5% of the earth's CHG. Water vapor is 95% of the earth's GHG and holds heat far longer than CO2.   
Lastly, CO2 will increase only after temperatures rise (eg. El Nino) and oceans degas. Conversely, CO2 levels drop as temperatures cool. In other words, CO2 levels are influenced by heat or the lack thereof and therefore do not drive climate but follow climate. 
Clearly, CO2 is actually a thermometer and not a thermostat!

This video is a lie. Exxon scientists did not invent the myth that buring fossil fuels cause "climate change". This idea originated in the 19th century with Svante Arrhenius following on from Joseph Fourier and John Tyndall. After Arrhenius the idea vanished for 40 years until a British railway engineer revived it. The idea was rejigged in its current (mathematical modelling) form by Gilbert Plass in the 1950s. His modelling methods were modified in the 1960s, '70s and '80s by several "scientists" (AKA armchair modellers - not actual scientists), over more than 20 years, such as Syukuro Manabe, Richard Wetherald, James Hansen culminating in a 2000 paper by Isaac Held and Brian Soden; which hasn't been changed much since. Many of the people who developed these models were trained in atmospheric physics. So 45 yeaars of mathematical/computer modelling and "Theory" (AKA speculation) are behind this man-made climate myth.

The scientists at Exxon were NOT climate scientists - they would've been geologists. The climate of earth is more than geoology and atmospheric physics. Climate sciences now involve 9, or so distinct sciences and disciplines: geology, atmospheric physics, Paleontology, Paleo-climatology , oceanograthy, meteorology, solar physics, astronomy, mathematical modelling. Because, contrary to what media ram into our heads, earth's climate is a complex thing. The atmospheric physicists and modellers who invented the greenhouse gas effect played upon this compelexity (too hard for hoi polloi to ken) to reduce everything to slogans the masses would understand and buy. Not saying they planned it that way, the the mill-machine of politics, media forced it down that route.

When Exxon scientists researched the majority of scientists working in climate fields disagreed with them. So if they were reluctant to publish maybe that was because they didn't want to sound like idiots?  Al Gore took the idea up after being exposed to it at a university lecture he attended. The IPCC was created to ONLY research man-made climate change, and told to find the evidence for it. 34 years later and they still have no good scientific evidence; but they get lots of funding and keep their cushy jobs in academia playing with their supercomputers; so what do they care about science and truth when they're paid to lie? Gore himself made sure that ONLY true believers in man-made climate got any government grants at all to study science. Yet despite the US government attempts to kill actual climate science (to replace it with group think) there are still many scientists today (more in Europe than the USA) who are interested in how the climate actually works. Scientists who don't think billionaires, government and politicians should decide scientific matters; to tell us what to think. Brave scientists who know that climate change is almost 100% natural - driven in the main - by changes in the complex relationships between earth and the sun, and mediated by cloud cover changes over earth, ocean currents and oceans storing heat like a giant luke warm water bottle would.

You can try to blame it on companies and governments, but no matter where you pass the buck, only a very very small portion of the population is prepared acknowledge their share of current pollution and change their lifestyle accordingly. There is no consensus among scientists to say the world is warming because of CO2. There is only a media consensus. The logarithmic diminution of the radiative forcing of CO2 will ensure there will be no increase in atmospheric temperature due to its increased presence in the atmosphere. This fact is well understood in the climate science community and can be accurately modelled using the Modtran program maintained and supported at the University of Chicago.The logarithmic diminution of the radiative forcing of CO2 is probably the reason why there was no runaway greenhouse warming from CO2 in earlier eons when CO2 levels were known to be at levels of several thousands ppmv (parts per million). Remarkably, IPCC published reports (TAR3) do actually acknowledge that the effective temperature increase caused by growing concentrations of CO2 in the atmosphere radically diminishes with those increasing concentrations. This information is in their report, Chapter 6. Radiative Forcing of Climate Change: section 6.3.4 Total Well-Mixed Greenhouse Gas Forcing Estimate.From the present concentration of atmospheric CO2 at approaching 415 ppmv, only 5% of the effectiveness of CO2 as a Greenhouse Gas remains. This can only give rise to a maximum of a further of +0.21°C. Thereafter beyond 1000+ ppmv the effect of increasing levels of CO2 can only ever be absolutely minimal, even if CO2 concentrations were to increase indefinitely.That is the science.

The IPCC stands for ‘Intergovernmental’ not ‘interdisciplinary’ panel on climate change - that already should make people realise that climate change is primarily a political and economic, not an environmental, scientific issue. The fact is that real science is never about consensus or settled. Who is conducting the peer reviews on this ‘settled’ science? It is my understanding that the peer review process is directed and overseen in-house by the IPCC, because their science is apparently settled. How does that make the process truly independent and interdisciplinary? 

So we are told that we only have a 12 year window of opportunity to stop catastrophic global warming. Okay, great, but what happens if nothing happens in 12 years and these predictions turn out wrong! Will I get my money back and will the IPCC be held accountable? 

I have noticed that when we get extreme cold spells it is referred to as weather, but when it gets hot it is climate change. Clearly the language is not intended to be manipulative. 

A two degree temperature increase will not permanently melt the poles or upend existing eco-systems. Nature is extremely resilient, adaptable and has  responded to and corrected environmental imbalances for hundreds of millions of years. Thus making nature far more adept at evolution and adaptation than us. There was a time, before humans, when the world was 13 degrees warmer than it is today and atmospheric CO2 concentrations were 2000 ppm. Currently CO2 concentration is around 380 ppm. Sure, the planet looked a little different then, but life was thriving and coral reefs existed in places that are now too cold. This is science fact, not speculation, which logically tells me that a two degree warming is very manageable in global and environmental terms. How humans will cope, however, is another issue. Judging by the mental meltdowns they are having over the speculation of what might be, doesn’t bode well for our species. 

I am if the opinion that the current take on climate change is akin to the believe in the end days. People wish it to be true because they convince themselves that everything is broken and the only way to fix it is to go through some cathartic change and where they imagine themselves as coming out empowered and on top. 

BTW, I am not a ‘denier’ of climate change. The climate has and continues to change and maybe humans do in some small way influence that change. I am all for studying and understanding this issue better. However, I do not subscribe to the militant ideologues and the opportunistic politics that are the elephant in the room of global warming.

Where has common sense gone? Is common sense no longer common? 
Is there really something like a true global climate? For example, at the equator there is a rainforest climate, around the Mediterranean they enjoy a Mediterranean climate and up north they have a Nordic climate. Around the world we find many different climates, warmer or colder, dry or wet with windy days. A "global climate" from only a temperature perspective makes absolutely no common sense! Why worry about a simple global mathematical average from temperatures sampled from many places over time? Obviously, the global climate from this single measurement does not exist anywhere on the planet because it is just a static figure down to a 1/10 of one Celsius degree. It seems silly that the worlds temperature represents climate in the same way as people's “average age” with half of the world’s population above and the younger 50% below middle to represents the calculated "human age". What would such global “human age” tell us about any specific individual? Nothing of course! So what does the “world temperature” tell us? Nothing, because such a “global temperature” is NOT something that can be experienced at any specific location. 

If we choose an arbitrary place, like a village in southern Scandinavia, the temperature at that village varies every single day by about 10 degrees between 25 degrees on a summer afternoon and 15 degrees late at night. During all four seasons of a year, the temperature in the same village can vary a lot more, maybe as much as 50 Celsius degrees, from icy -20 during a clear winter night to +30 degrees on balmy summer days. If the temperature at that village changes on average one degree here or there, it does not really matter at all for the villager’s life. Yet, we are bombarded by shrill preachers claiming that species will become extinct, and diversity will decline due to a one degree change in global mathematical average temperature. We are told about imminent "mass extinction events" and that human living conditions are guaranteed to be destroyed for sure. Really? What does your common sense say?  Could +26 degrees during the day and +16 at night eradicate fauna, flora, and microorganisms? The south part of Scandinavian has very different fauna, flora, and microorganisms than the central landscapes, or the wild northern regions. Spring comes to the south a month earlier than what they expect up north, etc. Common sense tells us that what is likely to happen, namely that some of the southern life forms will seen further north and bloom a little earlier during spring. Well, such healthy natural variation is precisely what scientists have observed from recorded treelines over thousands of years during a variety of historical climate conditions.

Should we trust what we are told or dare to trust our God given common sense?  Many are too easily frightened by all sorts of dire predictions and intimidating threats. Frightened people desperate for a cure for their anxiety will readily accept anything on offer. In a panicked climate context, it can be anything from stopping the use of cars, forsake air travel and cancelling holiday trips. Even rationing meat, reducing home heating or cooling, and discourage young children from dreaming of an interesting, bright, and active future lifestyle. 

It is noteworthy what the Nobel Laureate Manne Siegbahn once reminisced. When he began to study physics at the beginning of the last century, many academics like himself honestly believed that only a few more pieces of Mother Natures puzzle remained to be discovered and then science would have a complete holistic knowledge of the physical reality around us. However, it did not take long for extraordinary thinkers like Einstein, Planck and Bohr to name but a few, to open up large knowledge gaps in the picture and even to change the boundaries of already laid puzzle pieces. Today we are told with 100% certainty that the "science is settled" despite that history teaches us that the only thing we know for sure, is that we never know everything, especially about something as complicated and chaotic as Mother Natures climate system. This is not to say that we should ignore our precautionary principles, but we must also trust our common sense in the face of the many reckless political decisions that are rushed through only because the “Masters of Power” are 100% certain that we need to be saved from a imaginary world-wide "climate crisis". 

In their too common ignorance, our leading politicians seem to hope for a day when we will all be able to see with the naked eye that a climate crisis is raging outside the window, like an approaching comet. This is a futile hope because a changing climate is as invisible to the human eye as the molecules and atoms in our own body. Despite this, the old mass-media is desperate to link every hot day, every recent forest fire, a glacier caught melting, another drought, earthquakes, changing land and sea levels and flooding rains as if they were occurring for the first time in Earth's history and must therefore must be valid evidence proving "climate change". Globally we are just over one degree warmer today than during the "Little Ice Age" when the Thames froze over and millions of Europeans starved with numerous deaths. Scientists, journalists, or anyone should be sharing that during the "Little Ice Age" it was much colder globally, and since then the climate thankfully has improved until this day! 

But instead of being delighted about this climate normalisation they tell us that any increase in temperature is about "greenhouse heating" and it is our generations fault due to our irresponsibly luxurious way of life! Never are any other possible causes discussed than our modern way of living where energy from fossil fuel is the most important factor that has pulled us out of poverty. We are told that unless we funnel our economic powers into stopping the temperature from rising by another degree before the end of the century, we will waste "Planet One', and we will wipe out our civilization as we know it. We are told that the climate must and can be tamed and controlled by our generation of people by following the directives that politicians give us. The directives are made to influence every part of our daily lives. Previous climate history is ignored like the recent climate emergency that struck Europe in the 1860s. During that “Little Ice Age” summers went missing or were too short for farmers to grow and harvest crop. Few people have the stomach to reflect over the fact that such "Little Ice Age" could return at any time during coming decades. What social and logistic preparedness will be needed for our densely overpopulated world are questions that has become irrelevant because of the "Climate Crisis" in our overheating Bland New World.

Propaganda has historically been used for evil purposes - often influencing children and the young alike. It is favoured by dictators who are stuck in their own dogma regarding the politically acceptable. As a rule, the "Masters of Power" speak with well-chosen words, often in combination with adjectives such as emergency, crisis, and threats, so obedient people can be herded along a predetermined compass direction. Common sense means to look critically at the flow of messages and using our own intuitive examination of what can be regarded as moral, sensible, wise, and above all realistic. This is clearly not just a battle over “climate truth” and this fight will most likely never end. Today and during past millenniums, people has never known what the future may hold. With a reasonable outlook, humanity will be able to go where the future trends are heading and like every generation before us, we can trust our future descendants to live in ways that they find wise and justified, just like it always has been.

@weatheranddarkness Yes, you are right, the part of the atmosphere that is saturated is the troposphere. That is the part where we live. Are you one of those people who are alarmed by the claim that CO2 levels are at there highest in 800,000 years? If so, don't worry, the claim is simply a marketing ploy to scare the kiddies. It is meaningless. In terms of geological time 800,000 years is nothing. If the earth were a year old, 800 thousand years would amount to a mere 92 minutes. Would you judge a city's annual climate by a sample period of just 92 minutes? The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has reduced by about 90% over the past 150 million years. Even though its level has increased fractionally during the Holocene epoch, CO2 is still at an average of only 415 parts per million. Far from being a matter for alarm, this recent increase is most fortunate. After all, in order to survive, plants require an absolute minimum or 150 ppm atmospheric CO2. Many plants species suffer stress at amounts well above that. Immediately prior to the Holocene the level of CO2 went down to 180 ppm. We would not like to see that occur again. Since the Cambrian explosion atmospheric CO2 has averaged 2,000 ppm and through most of the Mesozoic era was at 3,000 ppm. It has been 300 million years since CO2 levels have been as low as they are today. It must be noted that at no time in the past did high levels of CO2 result in runaway climate change. The CO2/water vapour positive feedback loop has never occurred and will never occur. CO2 enrichment in greenhouses allows crops to meet their photosynthesis potential. The supply of extra CO2 is an often-applied method to increase the yield of greenhouse crops. The current hysteria over rising levels of atmospheric CO2 has no basis in science.

For me, the history of climate change started at the end of the French revolution, when Prof. „Baron de l'Empire“ Jean Baptiste Josef Fourier and chairman of a revolutionary committee, who was a mathematician and scientist who made many important discoveries and developed some mathematical processes, decided in 1824 to 1827 to calculate the energy balance of planet Earth. Since the climate gases and their impacts were not known at that time, he was astonished that his calculations resulted in an AVERAGE temperature on the planet that should be minus 15 deg. Centigrade or 5 deg. Fahrenheit, since he didn't know he had to consider the impacts of CO2 and Methane. (A few hundred years ago the instruments were not so precise, so the correct average should have been minus 18º C or -0.4º F). He published his results in „Mémoire sur les températures du globe terrestre et des espaces planétaires“ p.97-125
https://www.academie-sciences.fr/pdf/dossiers/Fourier/Fourier_pdf/Mem1827_p569_604.pdf

The climate gases were first discovered by American women's rights campaigner and scientist, who published her discoveries about the warming effect of climate gases in November 1856:
„Affecting the heat in the sun's rays” (American Journal of Science and Arts)
https://archive.org/details/mobot31753002152491/page/381/mode/2up?view=theater

From 1859 to 1862 Irish Professor John Tyndall did further research on climate gases.
https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/pdf/10.1098/rstl.1861.0001

Between 1896 and 1906 Swedish Professor and Nobel-Prize winner, Dr. Svante Arrhenius showed that the climate of the Earth is dependent on CO2 concentration.
1. https://www.rsc.org/images/Arrhenius1896_tcm18-173546.pdf
2. https://www.friendsofscience.org/assets/documents/Arrhenius%201906,%20final.pdf

In 1912 New Zeeland Newspaper „Rodney & Otamatea Times“ published a short article that due to the burning of coal the temperature of Earth would rise.
https://www.climateconversation.org.nz/wp/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/rodney-times-coal-burning-1912-720.jpg

In 1938 Guy Steward Callendar warned that global warming due to the Greenhouse Effect is already progressing.
http://www.met.reading.ac.uk/~ed/callendar_1938.pdf

During the 1940s (WWII) German meteorologist Hermann Flohn from the High Command of the German „Luftwaffe“ (Air Force) warned about the slow but contionueous rise of temperature. The article „Die Tätigkeit des Menschen als Klimafaktor“ was published in the magazin „Erdkunde“ (Geography) No. 9, 1941, Page 13 to 22.  (no online-copy available)  

The US Airforce did research on global warming in the 1940s, too.

1956 The UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs warns that the atmospheric CO2 concentration will rise 25% until the end of the century.

1957 scientists Roger Revelle and Hans Suess were surprised about the high concentration of fossil CO2 (proved by the Radiocarbon method).

1958 The US TV informs it viewers about global warning (see Leonardo de Caprio's movie about global warming)

1965 President Lyndon B. Johnson warns in a speech at the Congress about Global Warming and rising CO2-Levels, after having received a warning report from the governmental „Science Advisory Committee“ which was established in 1951 by Harry Trueman at the Dept. of Defense.
https://carnegiedge.s3.amazonaws.com/downloads/caldeira/PSAC,%201965,%20Restoring%20the%20Quality%20of%20Our%20Environment.pdf

In the second half of the 1960s and in the 1970s the issue of Global Warming was taken up by many national and international Organisations around the world.
All the predictions from the 70’s /80’s have not come true.

"Hypothesis....its all hypothetical."
No it isn't. Not anymore. It stopped being hypothetical in the mid to late 90s when the anthropogenic signature of warming emerged from the noise of natural variability. That the planet is warming at an unnatural rate is clearly observable in the past 20 years of temperature recordings. 

""Science" isn't 'consensus'...science is fact."
Science is the gradual validation of ever-refined hypotheses through observation and empirical evidence and consensus is the inevitable result of this process. 

"Models are based upon hypotheses...models have been SO exaggerated over time as to prove the models useless."

Climate models make use of vast quantities of data, and even early models from the 50s, 60s and 70s accurately predicted the warming that was recorded in the 2000s and 2010s. This isn't opinion. The Sun might be the primary driver of the _climate_ , but it isn't causing the climate _change_ , caused by GHG-induced warming, which the planet is experiencing now. We know that because we can measure solar irradiance (the amount of energy that reaches Earth), and that has been on the decline for the past four decades.
yet the sun has never beat down so hard.... and we've never experienced so many heat wave and floods like we currently are now.

"Climate change has been occurring for the entirety of human life on Earth."
Correct.

"Humans neither cause global warming, nor do they have a significant  role in its  cessation."
Bullshit. 

"The coming catastrophes will occur with volcanoes contributing as much as human kind."
Bullshit. Mankind emits approximately 60 times more greenhouse gases than the planet's volcanoes

 "We are moving into a global ice age, and humans cannot  ignore the obvious cause, our nearest star, the Sun."
Bullshit. Although solar irradiance (the amount of heat energy reaching Earth) has been in decline for four decades, and we _should_ be cooling, the 36 billion tons of greenhouse gases that man emits every year into our atmosphere more than counterbalances the cooling effect. _Only_ mankind's greenhouse gas emissions can explain the current rapid warming the planet is experiencing. 
 
"Climate change is a cycle that is not  caused by humans, plain and simple."
Bullshit. Climate change is caused by three fundamental forcings: changes in solar energy, changes in atmospheric gas concentrations, and changes is aerosols and particulates. Since mankind can have a considerable influence on the latter two, he can have a considerable impact on the climate. There is an abundance of evidence in the scientific literature that has established this.

"And why did they change it from Global Warming to Climate Change...is it because the climate started cooling and that didn't fit the narrative so they had to  change it to climate change that if its going down or up then its because of Climate change"
No. Not even close. The short answer is that nobody changed Global Warming to Climate Change. Both terms have been used in the scientific literature for at least the past 50 years. Furthermore, they refer to different phenomena. GW is simply the warming of the mean global surface temperature, whereas CC covers all the myriad impacts that GW has on the climate, such as changing rainfall patterns, harsher winters at some latitudes, more frequent storms in the tropics etc. They are not interchangeable terms, so GW can never simply change to CC. This is simply a myth being spread by mendacious politicians and commentators.

What unadulterated crap.   Why have none of the alarmist’s predictions come true?   All of the so called evidence, like more powerful storms, heat waves, floods, etc., are within the range of naturally occurring events.  So they can claim their proclamations of doom are accurate.    Doubt that the events claimed to fulfill their nonsense predictions are actually normal? Try explaining how 1936, 1934, 1921, and 1901 were very hot.  All of them before the CO2 levels were high.  Forest fires were much bigger back then too.  Many tropical cyclones were bigger back then also.   
The alarmists are doing their best to scare weak minded people into destroying Western Civilization.  
One need not be a climate scientist to see that the claims of the alarmists are lies.   One only needs to actually watch what they do.   Here are three “tells.”   Before listing the tells, let us review the claims made by the alarmists.   They say CO2 is so dangerous that we only have x number of years to stop it.  Of course x number of years depends on who the alarmist is.  Beginning in 1989 it was 10 years until Arctic Ice was gone.  Then it was moved to 2013, 2014, and now out to 2035.   They say global warming will cause crop failure.  People will starve by the thousands.  Storms will be worse.  Hot places will get hotter, cold places will get colder.  Basically the world, as we know it, will cease to exist.  Such doom and gloom.  
So if CO2 will cause all this, why do they oppose known ways to reduce CO2, and still have plentiful, reliable, and inexpensive energy?
The first tell.  They oppose building new hydroelectric plants, and even have shut some down.  Hydroelectric does not emit CO2, but it does generate electricity.   
The second tell.  They oppose the enhanced recovery technique that makes it possible to generate electricity using natural gas rather than coal.  This switch lowered the CO2 emissions of the US by a large amount.   This enhanced recovery technique allows copious amounts of gas to be extracted from shale.   It is called Fracking.  A contraction of hydraulic fracturing.   
Some say fracking is unsafe.   Really?  Compared to their doom and gloom?  How can a rare Fracking problem possibly compare to their doomsday scenario?  They oppose it with gusto!  Why would anyone do that IF CO2 is SO dangerous?
Third tell.   Most of the alarmists and their legions of useful idiots are also violently opposed to nuclear.   Nuclear has the capacity to produce all the electricity we need and with the exception of CO2 produced in making the reactors etc., generates zip, zero, nada CO2.   
But nuclear is too dangerous the alarmists cry.   Really?  Which one of the three nuclear accidents have caused droughts?   Which one caused more severe storms?  Which one has caused major forest fires, or crops to fail?   None of them have!
But what about the waste.  Modern nuclear reactors are more efficient that early ones.  The fuel can even be recycled.   The waste from a modern reactor can power a medium sized city for a year and produce enough waste to fill a shoe box.   There is ample area to store this for the foreseeable future.  
To me it is obvious the goal of the alarmists is not “saving the planet!”   Many of you need to wise up before it is too late!

I appreciate the video, but the assertion climate change was established by oil industry scientists in the 1970s is wildly inaccurate.  Fourier described the basic atmospheric physics in the 1820s. Keeling started tracking the relentless increase in CO2 in the 1950s.  None of this is new, although it did take until the 1970s until there was, by any reasonable measure, scientific consensus in Anthropogenic Climate Change.

Carbon dioxide is not a pollutant nor, by any stretch of the facts, is it a primary cause of global warming, the amount or warming it causes is minute. The Earth has warmed (from all causes including coming out of the last Ice-Age, which we are still in - there is ice covering the polar regions ) O.8°C in the last 100 years  The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, there because of human activity, is estimated to be (even by the alarmist's own figures) 0.016%. The huge cost (trillions of dollars) of removing that 0.016% would harm plant life and possibly (not certainly) reduce global temperature by about 0.1°F fifty years from now.

The main pollutant arising from the burning of fossil fuels is sulphur dioxide, which  has for a long time been 'scrubbed' or filtered out of industrial and vehicle emissions.  The UK by means of the Clean Air Acts prohibited the burning of coal and coke in open domestic fires back in the 1950's. Getting cleaner air had nothing at all to do with reducing carbon dioxide.

@-GinΠΓ Τάο Well axial tilt does a lot to keep the water masses circulating nutrients. The meeting of cold water bodies from the poles rich in oxygen and nutrients displace the warmer water masses in the tropics. These warm water masses are nutrient deserts so without continued circulation caused by the Coriolis effect our planet would be come banded in to oxic and anoxic rings. The rotation of the earth is a factor as well as the minor effect of the moons gravity affecting tides. The earth in relatively recent times (a few million years) was like a beautifully crafted Swiss Watch everything working together in biological harmony, until the advent of mankind who have broken the fragile equilibrium. Now on a geological time scale this was not always the case. The earth in it’s 4.5 Billion Year history has been just about everything from a molten poisonous volcanic inferno all the way through to becoming and ice covered snowball. Due to global tectonics the earths crust has been raised up from and subducted into the mantle many times with only a few vestiges of this original crust still extant today. We have been bombarded by a massive planet size object that created and formed our moon, the remains of that collision orbit between Jupiter and Mars as the Asteroid belt. The Pacific Ocean covers the hole that was caused by this. There have been six major extinctions between the Precambrian and the present. The most notable of these were the huge extinction event known as the ‘Great dying’ where 90 % of all life on earth was wiped out. This happened at the end of the Permian and the beginning of the Triassic. The second was the huge meteorite impact that wiped out 75% of all life at the end of the Cretaceous, taking with it the dinosaurs, ammonites and many of the primitive gymnosperm plant life. Since then furry rat like mammals evolved in what is known as the Tertiary and with the loss of the predominant ferns and gymnosperms, angiosperms ( flowering plants) became the predominant plant type. During this period the continents moved into the configuration we recognise today. The major ice ages ended the Tertiary and we live in the Holocene/anthropocene. Now for the first time in our planets vast history an organism has arisen that has ability to change our planet and not for the better, man. The earth will survive but we will not. If anything intelligent comes after us they will notice a thin band of radioactive fossilised plastics which will be the only relic that we ever existed, and maybe the odd rare bone. For all our hubris and fury this will be what is left.

Prove your claims.

"


"Human activities emit 60 or more times the amount of carbon dioxide released by volcanoes each year. Large, violent eruptions may match the rate of human emissions for the few hours that they last, but they are too rare and fleeting to rival humanity’s annual emissions. In fact, several individual U.S. states emit more carbon dioxide in a year than all the volcanoes on the planet combined do.

Volcanic v. human emissions of CO2
On the scale of carbon dioxide emissions, human sources far outweigh volcanoes. NOAA Climate.gov cartoon by Emily Greenhalgh.

Human activities
Human activities—mostly burning of coal and other fossil fuels, but also cement production, deforestation and other landscape changes—emitted roughly 40 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide in 2015. Since the start of the Industrial Revolution, more than 2,000 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide have been added to the atmosphere by human activities according to the Global Carbon Project.

Volcanic versus anthropogenic CO2 emissions
Since the start of the Industrial Revolution, human emissions of carbon dioxide from fossil fuels and cement production (green line) have risen to more than 35 billion metric tons per year, while volcanoes (purple line) produce less than 1 billion metric tons annually. NOAA Climate.gov graph, based on data from the Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center (CDIAC) at the DOE's Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Burton et al., 2013.

Volcanoes
Volcanoes emit carbon dioxide in two ways: during eruptions and through underground magma. Carbon dioxide from underground magma is released through vents, porous rocks and soils, and water that feeds volcanic lakes and hot springs. Estimates of global carbon dioxide emissions from volcanoes have to take both erupted and non-erupted sources into account.

Mount Merapi degassing
Much of the carbon dioxide released by volcanoes is emitted by degassing of subterranean magma when the volcano is not erupting. In this photo, volcanic gases and steam rise from Mount Merapi, Indonesia, on May 20, 2012. Creative Commons license by Jimmy McIntyre.

In a 2011 peer-reviewed paper, U.S. Geologic Survey scientist Terry Gerlach summarized five previous estimates of global volcanic carbon dioxide emission rates that had been published between 1991 and 1998. Those estimates incorporated studies reaching back to the 1970s, and they were based on a wide variety of measurements, such as direct sampling and satellite remote sensing. The global estimates fell within a range of about 0.3 ± 0.15 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide per year, implying that human carbon dioxide emissions were more than 90 times greater than global volcanic carbon dioxide emissions.

Mount Saint Helens erupting
On May 18, 1980, Mount Saint Helens experienced an explosive eruption, sending a column of ash, steam, and gases up to 60,000 feet above sea level. For about nine hours, carbon dioxide emissions from the volcano may have matched human emissions, but such massive eruptions are rare and fleeting. U.S. Geological Survey photo by Robert Krimmel.

In 2013, another group of scientists—Michael Burton, Georgina Sawyer, and Domenico Granieri—published an updated estimate using more data on carbon dioxide emissions from subsurface magma that had become available in the years since the last global estimate. While acknowledging a large range of variability in the estimates, the authors concluded that the best overall estimate was about 0.6 billion metric tons of carbon dioxide per year.

While higher than Gerlach's estimate, the figure is still just a fraction of carbon dioxide output from human activities. Gerlach remarked via email, “Taken at face value, their result implies that anthropogenic CO2 exceeds global volcanic CO2 by at least a factor of 60 times.”

Occasionally, eruptions are powerful enough to release carbon dioxide at a rate that matches or even exceeds the global rate of human emissions for a few hours. For example, Gerlach estimated that the eruptions of Mount St. Helens (1980) and Pinatubo (1991) both released carbon dioxide on a scale similar to human output for about nine hours. Human emissions of carbon dioxide continue day after day, month after month, year after year.

Today versus the past
Volcanic activity today may pale in comparison to the carbon dioxide emissions we are generating by burning fossil fuels for energy, but over the course of geologic time, volcanoes have occasionally contributed to global warming by producing significant amounts of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.

For example, some geologists hypothesize that 250 million years ago, an extensive flood of lava poured continually from the ground in Siberia perhaps hundreds of thousands of years. This large-scale, long-lasting eruption likely raised global temperatures enough to cause one of the worst extinction events in our planet's history. Current volcanic activity doesn't occur on the same massive scale.

Climate cooling
Today, rather than warming global climate, volcanic eruptions often have the opposite effect. That's because carbon dioxide isn't the only thing that volcanoes inject into the atmosphere. Even small eruptions often produce volcanic ash and aerosol particles.


Taken by astronauts from the Space Shuttle in early August 1991, this photo of the Earth's limb shows the double layer of volcanic aerosol particles (interpretation from Self et al., 1999) that spread through the stratosphere following the catastrophic eruption of Mt. Pinatubo. Encircling the globe at altitudes even higher than the tops of thunderstorm clouds, the particles reflected so much incoming sunlight that global surface temperatures cooled off for two years. Photo courtesy NASA JSC's Gateway to Astronaut Photography of the Earth.

Whether from small or large eruptions, volcanic aerosols reflect sunlight back into space, cooling global climate. The 1815 eruption of Mount Tambora produced enough ash and aerosols to cancel summer in Europe and North America in 1816.

References
Boden, T.A., Marland, G., Andres, R.J. (2015). Global, Regional, and National Fossil-Fuel CO2 Emissions, Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Burton, M.R., Sawyer, G.M., Granieri, D. (2013). Deep carbon emissions from volcanoes. Reviews in Mineralogy and Geochemistry, 75, 323–354.

Cook, J. (2015). Do volcanoes emit more CO2 than humans? Skeptical Science. Accessed May 11, 2016.

Gerlach, T. (2011). Volcanic versus anthropogenic carbon dioxide. EOS, 92(24), 201–202.

Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. (2007, February 20). Which produces more CO2, volcanic or human activity? U.S. Geological Survey. Accessed May 11, 2016.

Houghton, R.A., van der Werf, G.R., DeFries, R.S., Hansen, M.C., House, J.I., Le Quéré, C., Pongratz, J., Ramankutty, N. (2012). Chapter G2 Carbon emissions from land use and land-cover change, Biogeosciences, 9, 5125-514.

IPCC. (2014). Summary for Policymakers. In: Climate Change 2014: Mitigation of Climate Change. The IPCC was created in 1988 largely due to the efforts of Maurice Strong, a oil, gas and power billionaire and self-confessed socialist, as part of a larger campaign to justify giving the United Nations the authority to tax businesses in developed countries and redistribute trillions of dollars a year to developing nations. 

Strong had previously succeeded in bringing about the creation of the UN Environment Programme in 1972 and served as its first executive director. The IPCC is a joint project of that entity and the World Meteorological Organization.

(Strong was subsequently implicated in corruption surrounding the UN’s Oil-for-Food-Program and has resigned from his UN positions. 
According to John Izzard writing for the Australian publication Quadrant Online,  “Following his exposure for bribery and corruption in the UN’s Oil-for-Food scandal Maurice Strong was stripped of many of his 53 international awards and honours he had collected during his lifetime working in dual role of arch conservationist and ruthless businessman.

https://quadrant.org.au/opinion/doomed-planet/2015/12/discovering-maurice-strong/

A superb political operator, in 1972 he set up a UN “Environment Conference” in Stockholm, to declare that the Earth’s resources were the common inheritance of all mankind. They should no longer be exploited for the benefit of only a few countries, at the expense of poorer countries across the globe.

To pursue this, he became founding director of a new agency, the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), and in the Eighties he took up the cause of a tiny group of international meteorologists who had come to believe that the world faced catastrophic warming. In 1988, UNEP sponsored this little group into setting up the UN’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).

In 1992, now allied with the IPCC, Strong pulled off his greatest coup when he set up another new body, the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), to stage that colossal “Earth Summit” over which he presided in Rio, arranging for it to be attended not only by 108 world leaders and 100,000 others but also by 20,000 UN-funded “green activists”.

It is the UNFCCC which in effect has dictated the global climate change agenda ever since. Almost yearly it has staged huge conferences, notably those at Kyoto (1997), Copenhagen (2009) and the present one in Paris. And all along it has been Strong’s ideology, enshrined at Rio in “Agenda 21”, which has continued to shape the entire process, centred on the principle that the richer developed countries must pay for a problem they created, to the financial benefit of all those “developing countries” that have been its main victims.

In 2005, Strong was caught having been illicitly paid $1 million from the UN’s Oil for Food programme, supposedly set up to allow Saddam Hussein to pay in oil to feed starving Iraqis. He retired to a flat in Beijing, where he had been close to China’s Communist leaders back to Mao. It was from there that he returned home to Canada to die,on November 27.

"Strong’s dream is more than ever falling apart"

To this day, global climate policy is still shaped by Strong’s Agenda 21, as was highlighted last February when Christiana Figueres, the Costa Rican Marxist now head of the UNFCCC and organiser of the Paris conference, urged that the West should give “$1 trillion a year” to the “developing” world.

But the wonderful irony is that the reason why Paris will fail, like Copenhagen before it, is that those “developing countries”, led by China and India – now the world’s first and third largest “CO2 emitters” – have not the slightest intention of curbing their emissions. It is for the West to do that, for creating “the problem”. Thus, just as he died, Strong’s dream is more than ever falling apart – thanks to those very countries his socialist vision was intended to help.

"Claims of unprecedented carbon-dioxide levels ignore most of Earth’s 4.6-billion-year history. Relative to Earth’s entire record, carbon-dioxide levels are at historically low levels; they only appear high when compared to the dangerously low levels of carbon dioxide that occurred in Earth’s very recent history. The geologic record reveals carbon dioxide has almost always been in Earths’ atmosphere in much greater concentrations than it is today. For example, 600 million years ago, when history’s greatest birth of new animal species occurred, atmospheric carbon-dioxide concentrations exceeded 6,500 parts per million (ppm) — an amount that’s 17 times greater than it is today.

Atmospheric carbon dioxide is currently only 410 parts per million. That means only 0.04 percent of our atmosphere is carbon dioxide (compared to 0.03 percent one century ago). Only one molecule in 2,500 is carbon dioxide. Such levels certainly do not pose a health risk, as carbon-dioxide levels in our naval submarines, which stay submerged for months at a time, contain an average carbon-dioxide concentration of 5,000 ppm.

The geologic record is important because it reveals relationships between carbon-dioxide levels, climate, and life on Earth. Over billions of years, the geologic record shows there is no long-term correlation between atmospheric carbon-dioxide levels and Earth’s climate. There are periods in Earth’s history when carbon dioxide concentrations were many times higher than they are today, yet temperatures were identical to, or even colder than, modern times. The claim that fossil-fuel emissions control atmospheric carbon-dioxide concentrations is also invalid, as atmospheric concentrations have gone up and down in the geological record, even without human influence.

The absurdity of climate alarmism claims gets even stranger when you consider there are 7.5 billion people on our planet who, together, exhale 2.7 billion tons of carbon dioxide each year, which is almost 10 percent of total fossil-fuel emissions every year. However, we are but a single species. Combined, people and all domesticated animals contribute 10 billion tons.

Further, 9 percent of carbon-dioxide emissions from all living things arise not from animals, but from anaerobic bacteria and fungi. These organisms metabolize dead plant and animal matter in soil via decay processes that recycle carbon dioxide back into the atmosphere. The grand total produced by all living things is estimated to be 440 billion tons per year, or 13 times the amount of carbon dioxide currently being produced by fossil-fuel emissions. Fossil-fuel emissions are less than 10 percent of biological emissions. Are you laughing yet?"- Excerpt from an article written by Jay Lehr (Internationally renowned scientist and Senior Policy Advisor with the International Climate Science Coalition and Senior Science Analyst at CFACT) and Tom Harris (Executive director of the International Climate Science Coalition.)

It's rubbish and does not happen in the real atmosphere. There is no such thing as a "Greenhouse Effect".

In the real atmosphere, increasing CO2 doesn't and can't increase the temperature of the troposphere in any measurable way. In other words, the climate sensitivity is essentially zero.

Only an increase in insolation, an increase in surface pressure, an increase in molar mass, or a decrease in atmospheric density will increase the surface temperature significantly.

My videos explain why in fine detail; it's because there is no 'greenhouse gas warming effect' and there is no special group of gases called 'greenhouse gases' which can cause anomalous warming of the atmosphere. Neither of these exist on any planet - including Earth.

If you are wondering; yes, I'm a climate scientist, a PhD in climate science.

My two recently published climate papers invalidate the so-called "Greenhouse Gas Warming Effect" in two completely different ways;

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/324599511_Thermal_Enhancement_on_Planetary_Bodies_and_the_Relevance_of_the_Molar_Mass_Version_of_the_Ideal_Gas_Law_to_the_Null_Hypothesis_of_Climate_Change

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335927448_On_the_Apparent_Relationship_Between_Total_Solar_Irradiance_and_the_Atmospheric_Temperature_at_1_Bar_on_Three_Terrestrial-type_Bodies

All of it is about radiative interations - but radiative interactions only dominate heat transfer in the mesosphere and the statosphere - not in the troposphere.

We live in the troposphere, and there heat transfer is totally dominated by convection.

Convection occurs in the parts of all planetary atmospheres which are over a pressure of 10kPa. This causes convection and a thermal gradient to appear.

The residual warming effect is the difference between the effective temperature and the measured surface temerature.

@Ian of Liverpool Hey, I'm just gonna reply in the two comments I see you copy-pasting this. Sure most CO2 emission come from natural cause, and that human's miniscule input may seem insignificant.

But, remember that the natural CO2 back then were a part of a naturally balanced system/cycle. That, before human slowly increased and affect the CO2 emissions, earth had a fragile cycle to heat and _cool_ itself down.

But now that we added more CO2 into the atmosphere, that cycle is not interrupted and the earth is indeed getting hotter at an unnatural rate. You could even say it spiked, not just increase, but _spiking_.

You could see how the graph (and CO2 emission from human causes, let the graph to spike) from these video.

Take your pick.

And, if we continue to let the CO2 increase, and decrease natural land (trees or what have you) to make for more housing and fuel burning without stop— that natural cycle isn't going to keep up. Leading to the greenhousing CO2 from us (and natural causes) from the years before to stack up and make the earth even warmer, which leads to more residual CO2 next year, that'll make the earth even more next year, and so on and so forth.

So, small as it may, it does tip a delicate balance for humanity and is one of the cause, the main cause, for global warming.

If we want to effectively tackle these problems, what we need is to focus only on measures that have a real impact

1) distance tax: a tax that increases the longer the goods are shipped or transported- this incentivizes a local economy and stops the mess of goods running around the world for no reason.

2) female education- the more educated the less children they will have, as overpopulation is a huge problem

3) tackle income inequality- tax the super wealthy and the multinationals, make them pay the right share, no more tax avoidance or producing in countries with lower regulations. Big companies need the most resources and make up the biggest polluters, so local and smaller is better.

4) universal basic income so people dont have "to make a living" at any cost and follow their passions- no damaging, stupid or unnecessary work

5) make hemp biodiesel (and other biodiesels) make up 30% of all fuel compulsory in the economy and make investments. Tackle food waste and make it maximal 5% of all produced. Go towards 0% fossil fuels with improved technology. Swap most plastics for hemp-derived materials

6) sustainability index- make an index of the worst environmental offender-practices. Ban those that are not needed and bring within limits those that can be made sustainable. Use taxes to incentivize/disincentivize

7) go towards a bio-adapted infrastructure such as passages for the wild under highways and so forth. Go back to natural farming, drop all intensive farming, is healthier anyway. Decrease production of animal products. Abandon chemicals, fertilizers and pesticides, all not sustainable. 

8) we need a working UN back in some form, to protect areas such as the amazonas and other strategically important parts of the world for the ecology. Besides that we need first nation countries to invest in countries that are lagging behind, as the investment would yield much greater results. This is a global challenge.

9) drop all the measures that wont make any difference and accept that we cant control it 100% at this point. Maybe there are some benefits in a warmer climate too.

Some facts. Historically from ice core samples the CO2 levels have risen 800 - 1400 years AFTER global warming. In the past 1 million years the CO2 levels have never been higher than 300 ppm, which they are now exceeding, but before that the CO2 levels were very much higher, up to 5000ppm. Animal evolved in this time so there is no reason to suppose that higher CO2 will lead to an extinction event or that there will be a runaway. All these facts are readily identifiable from many sources on the internet, you do not have to take my word for it.
A scientific theory or law represents a hypothesis (or group of related hypotheses) which has been confirmed through repeated testing, almost always conducted over a span of many years. Generally, a theory is an explanation for a set of related phenomena, like the theory of evolution or the big bang theory. Global warming models have not yet been able to predict the future climate so the current status is one of a hypothesis. Science must always incorporate new data. The reason that people say "Climate science is established – we are in the midst of a climate emergency." is for political not scientific reasons. _I can only direct you to the actual IPCC text relating to this matter, See Table 12.4, page 1115, dealing with abrupt and irreversible changes_
I know that the IPCC releases their reports to the public. I hadn't read this one though, because it's from 2013. The more recent ones can be found here : https://www.ipcc.ch/library/ and here https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/ (not that I'd claim to have read them all, obviously). 
Regardless of this I read the one you linked. But I also actually read the text surrounding the table the specifically referred to, that says e.g. "most aspects of the climate
change resulting from CO2 emissions are irreversible, due to the long residence time of the CO2 perturbation in the atmosphere and the resulting warming". I assume when referring to the table as an argument for your claim that tipping points aren't a thing or at least nothing to really worry about (is that the point you're making?) you're talking about the 3rd column "Reversible". Apart from the fact that it says for most reversible on a time scale of centuries to millennia (i.e. not reversible within a human life-span), the table reads "Reversible *if forcing reversed* ". 
Now what does mean? Climate forcing - to put it simple - is the induction of energy into the climate system via various factors. A reversed forcing would be a scenario in which the total energy in the climate system actually shrinks (e.g. via a reduction in atmospheric CO2 concentration). The presence of such a scenario is the assumption under which this table operates. To go back to our forest fire analogy for a moment: The table doesn't deal with the question: _Will the fire continue to spread if we stop dumping fuel into the fire? _ but rather: _Can we regrow the forest after the fire was ended? _ ... In words: The table doesn't deal with tipping points. If you want to read an IPCC report that does deal with tipping points; this should be the most recent one: https://www.ipcc.ch/srocc/chapter/chapter-6/ or if you want to "drink from the source" even more directly; this is one of the papers the report cites: https://www.nature.com/articles/nclimate2964

_people need to be able to perform cost benefit calculations to know what is worth doing. To do these calculations we need not only that X causes Y but how much X causes Y, probabilities and are there other relevant factors which we have ignored_
Scientists *do* these calculations. The very paper I just linked you does for example (which is obviously the reason I specifically picked it). It gives calculations for the annual social costs of 1 ton of CO2 for the future under different scenarios giving - of course - probabilities and confidence intervals for the values they arrive at. It's rather short and not too hard to read so I'd recommend you give it read, but if you just want a quick number. Under a baseline scenario (i.e. with only limited efforts to decarbonize) the social costs of of 1t of CO2 could reasonably as high as $450/t by 2060 and $750/t by 2100. For the US, at current emission rates, that would be an *annual* cost of roughly 2.3 trillion US$ (3.8 trillion US$ by 2100).  And that is not even factoring in indirect and non-climate change related social costs of fossil fuel use like an increased chance of getting lung cancer.

The gist is basically: Decarbonizing has a high upfront cost, but if you look past the next couple decades the cost of decarbonization are negligible in comparison to the costs of not mitigation climate change.

There is based on ice core studies (there are uncertainties as to how accurate those Co2 measurements are due to pressure effects and the transfer of dissolved gases through ice by water flow, in any case they do not represent spot levels but averages over varying periods of time)  no overall paleoclimate correlation between rising Co2 levels and warming, the REVERSE IS TRUE, temperatures usually rise first THIS DRIVES UP Co2 with around an 800 year lag, but higher Co2 levels DO NOT STOP temperatures dropping which results in lowering of Co2 levels as colder oceans can hold MORE Co2 in solution, conversly WARMING oceans cannot hold as much Co2 in solution and outgass more into the atmosphere.
We do have fossil leaf stomata evidence from the Holocene thermal optimum of atmospheric Co2 levels of around 500 ppm, this is likely to be more accurate than ice core measurements.
There is overall only around a 15% correlation between rising Co2 levels and warming.
This is why researching the paleoclimate is important it allows you to put things into an accurate context.
Co2 may or may not produce atmospheric warming, this is yet to be settled, the limited experimental data we have says NO but this needs multiple replication.
If Co2 does provide warming to the atmosphere its effect will be strictly limited, this is because the effect will be logarithmic not linear, if Co2 warms its greatest warming effect will be at 20 ppm, with each subsequent doubling of Co2 in the atmosphere the additional warming produced will be smaller and smaller, assuming Co2 does warm, currently Co2 has used around 87% of its ability to warm, at 410 ppm we could double the concentration of Co2 without producing more than a small additional warming.

I am always amazed to see anyone believe the lie about the oceans levels flooding the earth. Have you ever tried the simplest demonstration of this ? Fill a glass with ice ( crushed or cubed ) then top it off with as much water as you can, then let it sit at room temperature. The glass never will run over. Yes there will be some water at the base from condensation, but the water level in the glass goes down. And this is just a flat surface. As far as I know there are no energy companies with thorium reactors, and it's true they're not just waiting to be built. But there are coalitions and research that is pushing *for the development of* thorium reactors. Fusion is in that stage of development and it's extremely hard from what I've heard. Thorium already has the groundwork for function, all that needs to be done is to fully flesh it out. My question is, if fusion is a lot harder, why build, test, and improve fusion? Does fusion have some long term advantage over thorium? When you compare the two, thorium makes more sense. At least that's how I see it.

@Saucine Let me turn this question around: Why would an energy company want to endlessly buy or mine for coal (and endlessly pay money) if they could just get so much energy from 1kg of thorium? Energy companies sell energy. They don't sell coal. The cheaper they can produce the energy the better for them. The reason why thorium rectors aren't being used is because there are no working thorium rectors. 
I'm not saying the concept wasn't sound. But as somebody working in research and development I can tell you that there is a world between having _a sound concept_ or even _a working prototype_ and having a functional end product. And people who pretend that thorium reactors are basically just waiting to be built are doing so either a) because they don't know any better or b) because they are being willfully dishonest.

@Ian of Liverpool Hey, I'm just gonna reply in the two (well three now) comments I see you copy-pasting this. Sure most CO2 emission come from natural cause, and that human's miniscule input may seem insignificant.

But, remember that the natural CO2 back then were a part of a naturally balanced system/cycle. That, before human slowly increased and affect the CO2 emissions, earth had a fragile cycle to heat and _cool_ itself down.

But now that we added more CO2 into the atmosphere, that cycle is not interrupted and the earth is indeed getting hotter at an unnatural rate. You could even say it spiked, not just increase, but _spiking_.

You could see how the graph (and CO2 emission from human causes, let the graph to spike) from these video.

A calmer, clinical, and skeptical look on climate change: https://youtu.be/uqwvf6R1_QY

A more humorous, snappy, though showed how the CO2 emission affected the atmosphere more clearly imo in this video: https://youtu.be/R7FAAfK78_M

Take your pick.

Not to mention that even if Volcanoes or what have you erupted, it _also_ releases a cooling gas (I believe it was sulphur but I could be wrong) that counters the affect of its heat while humans _doesn't_ do that. And, if we continue to let the CO2 increase, and decrease natural land (trees or what have you) to make for more housing and fuel burning without stop— that natural cycle isn't going to keep up. Leading to the greenhousing CO2 from us (and natural causes) from the years before to stack up and make the earth even warmer, which leads to more residual CO2 next year, that'll make the earth even more next year, and so on and so forth.

So, small as it may, it does tip a delicate balance for humanity and is one of the cause, the main cause, for global warming.

@Powdered Phantom "...the effect you’re describing basically has the same out come."
No.  It doesn't.  Each molecule of air is only capable of "reflecting" particular wavelengths of light, depending on the chemical composition of each molecule.  Nitrogen (the vast bulk of the atmosphere) can only "reflect" high ultraviolet (UV).  Carbon dioxide can only "reflect" particular wavelengths of infrared (IR).

The Nongovernmental International Panel on Climate Change (NIPCC) is an international panel of nongovernment scientists and scholars who have come together to present a comprehensive, authoritative, and realistic assessment of the science and economics of global warming. Because it is not a government agency, and because its members are not predisposed to believe climate change is caused by human greenhouse gas emissions, NIPCC is able to offer an independent unbias expert opinion of the evidence reviewed – or not reviewed – by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) on the issue of global warming.

NIPCC seeks to objectively analyze and interpret data and facts without conforming to any specific agenda. This organizational structure and purpose stand in contrast to those of the United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), which is government-sponsored, politically motivated, and predisposed to believing that climate change is a problem in need of a U.N. solution.

Wow, you are really biased. I get that you like sarcasm but please, you claim to be a science channel but you cannot even talk without 'attacking' (for lack of a better word) the opposing argument. Full disclosure: I am not a climate change skeptic, I just care about the way information is presented. Instead of using the ad hominem fallacy over and over, how about trying to neutrally report your position with evidence to support. 

Example from the video: "the debate on climate change has been long, complex and intense. This is of course not true because according to their own science..." (I don't really feel like typing the whole thing out so from 4:18-4:33)

That statement is factually accurate because climate scientists have been trying to figure out all of the effects of climate change for several years now (and we are still trying to figure out the effects). It's a fricking world climate with so many countries, companies, variables, etc. Climate scientists are still not 100% certain of what will happen. That's why, if you read the IPCC's most recent report (the staying under 1.5 C), you can see that there is a TON of things they have to talk about, and within each one, they list off the things they are 'confident' in and how much evidence supports it. According to their charts, they have varying levels of confidence (from low confidence to high confidence). Medium confidence is about 50% certainty an outcome will occur which doing a simple Ctrl-F will reveal dozens of times "medium confidence" appears in their report. Meaning that there is uncertainty about certain outcomes. Which means that it's debated.

SO. TLDR; Climate change is an ongoing debate, and it has been long, it has been complex, and one could classify as intense if they wanted to. However, the existence of climate change is real, and the statement made by that ad was accurate thus invalidating one of AsapSCIENCE's argument points. 

My opinion: This guy talking is too passionate and needs to report information in an unbiased manner; his emotions on the topic cloud his judgment to make reasonable points of opposition.

Robbie Scrivener 3 more things.. 1). CO2 is necessary!! with out it we would surely freeze as a significant amount of the suns light would be lost to space. However, just like life, its a delecate balance; too little we freeze, to much we fry. 2). the regulation of CO2 in our atmosphere is controlled by our oceans (which turn CO2 into carbonic acid) and by, as we all know, photosynthesis. These two constants have in the past kept the PPM of CO2 in our atmosphere from tipping the scales. but our oceans are becoming saturated and acidifying, and our plant life is burning. Our biosphere is losing its natural regulators. so atmospheric CO2 is rising. because of this our planet is steadily warming. 3). There are several positive feed back mechanisms that our accelerating the warming of our planet. lets start with permafrost. permafrost is frozen plant matter stored in ice around our northern hemisphere. this plant matter has yet to decay, so its methane and CO2 are sealed like in a vault. the warming of our planet is causing these vaults to "open", or in reality “melt”. the contents of these vaults are enough to significantly increase the atmospheres ability to trap heat, and will itself accelerate the melting of more permafrost. this is the feed back loop that is occurring right now. the next feed back loop is the demisinishing of reflective surfices. Ice is the most reflective surface on our planet, and water is the most light absorbant. as the ice sheets melt, more of the surface of our globe will be able to absorb more energy (light or heat. all are synonymous). this will increase the temperature of the ocean and continue to melt more ice. this is the feed back loop that will, just as the previous loop, accelerate itself. the last feed back loop is the destruction of forests. whether by man or by fire, our forests are disappearing. because of the rise in heat wave, forest fires are burning more often, with more intesity, over larger swaths of forested land. this year alone saw more forest fires than has ever recorded. our forests, as any child knows, converts CO2 into sugar and O2 as part of its respitory cycle we call photosynthesis. when these trees burn, they not only stop the gas conversion, but release their stored CO2 back into the atmosphere to further warm the planet, and increase the capacity of forest fires to burn. This is final feed back loop.

Climatologists are not scientists. They are weathermen. Weathermen that estimate what the Earth's climate was in the past using surrogates such as tree ring growth patterns, pollen counts and air bubbles trapped in ice sheets. CO2 is 0.04% of the atmosphere.

@Auke Meijer UAH data (1979-2019) has observed temps increasing by 0.13C/decade. I guess I think of "rapid" as being faster than ~1.5C in 100 years. The idea that it is "direct intervention by Humans" doing it is similarly contestable. Even just the idea that it is CO2 alone - while CO2 has gone up pretty steadily, temps over the 20th century fluctuated. The 1930s were very warm, the 1970s saw cooling, the first 15-20 years of the 21st century saw relative stagnation. There are a lot of factors.
The idea that increased temps will cause disasters is just propaganda. There's no evidence to support it. Rates of drought, heatwaves and floods have not been increasing, and historically when temps have been warmer than today (eg Roman Warming Period, Medieval Warming Period) the times have been more prosperous and wealthy. Better harvests, less starvation, a healthier population and spare resources to go build cathedrals and so forth. Conversely, cooler periods see failed harvests, starvation and poverty. In broad terms, warm is good and cold is bad.

The average temperature of the Earth's surface is 14.7C
However if you calculate it as (average T^4)^0.25 it is about a degree hotter
So 15C ain't far wrong either way.

However the theoretical temperature based on sunlight hitting the Earth is -19C. Right there is why the GH effect is usually stated as being 34C, its the difference between -19C and 15C.

However the surface (sea level) might not be the right place to calculate the theoretical temperature, if the right place is in the atmosphere the real GH effect is less than 34C. A tiny bit less, a lot less, could it even be zero? A good question but now you need new theories and a supercomputer.
No

The GH effect was not discovered or proven in the 1800s. The experiment by Arrhenius showed that CO2  absorbed some radiation better than other gasses, it was then speculated that the atmosphere might be the cause of the 34C anomaly that came to be called the GH effect. What is rarely pointed out is that the entire 34C effect is a result of calculating the temperature balance at sea level. There is zero evidence that sea level is where the temperature balance should be. Convection and evaporation both drive the balance upwards and at about 5km up the GH effect is zero.
Though scientists have shown that temperature correlates with CO2 it isn't clear if it follows, leads or both are driven by something else. It may interest you that Earth has had much higher CO2 and much higher temperatures in the past, what we have now is actually unusually low for both.

@Ian of Liverpool  Hey, I'm just gonna reply in the two comments I see you copy-pasting this. Sure most CO2 emission come from natural cause, and that human's miniscule input may seem insignificant.

But, remember that the natural CO2 back then were a part of a naturally balanced system/cycle. That, before human slowly increased and affect the CO2 emissions, earth had a fragile cycle to heat and _cool_ itself down.

But now that we added more CO2 into the atmosphere, that cycle is not interrupted and the earth is indeed getting hotter at an unnatural rate. You could even say it spiked, not just increase, but _spiking_.

You could see how the graph (and CO2 emission from human causes, let the graph to spike) from these video.

A calmer, clinical, and skeptical look on climate change: https://youtu.be/uqwvf6R1_QY

A more humorous, snappy, though showed how the CO2 emission affected the atmosphere more clearly imo in this video: https://youtu.be/R7FAAfK78_M

Take your pick.

Not to mention that even if Volcanoes or what have you erupted, it _also_ releases a cooling gas (I believe it was sulphur but I could be wrong) that counters the affect of its heat while humans _doesn't_ do that. And, if we continue to let the CO2 increase, and decrease natural land (trees or what have you) to make for more housing and fuel burning without stop— that natural cycle isn't going to keep up. Leading to the greenhousing CO2 from us (and natural causes) from the years before to stack up and make the earth even warmer, which leads to more residual CO2 next year, that'll make the earth even more next year, and so on and so forth.

So, small as it may, it does tip a delicate balance for humanity and is one of the cause, the main cause, for global warming.

There is still no empirical evidence that CO2 causes global warming  (correlation does not imply causation).   An increasing greenhouse effect depends upon increased re-radiation from CO2 in the atmosphere, and this manifests itself as a tropical tropospheric hotspot, plus increased Downwelling Longwave Radiation (DLR) which warms the surface.   However, this hostspot and increasing DLR has never been detected.  In which case, CO2 is not causing global warming.

And we know this because during the ice ages - when CO2 levels were high the world cooled, and when CO2 levels was low the world warmed.  The climate would not do that, if CO2 was the primary feedback agent.  In reality, the primary feedback agent is albedo (reflectivity), which explains all aspects of the ice age temperature cycle.  Please see my latest science paper on CO2, which demonstrates that during the ice ages CO2 was NOT controlling world temperature.  
Modulation of Ice Ages via Dust and Albedo:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1674987116300305

Jewelry Springer EV’s are definitely better. If we just take out the CO2 argument for a moment. Limiting particle pollution in cities is a win for everybody. 

The general complaint about EV’s are that they are coal powered, well, there’s an easy fix to that. Stop using coal! I’ve lived on two different power grids in my adult life, one was 100% renewable, the one i live in now is about 50%. So already there my EV would be a net benefit to CO2 emissions. But the larger discussion is not about now, it’s about the electrification of out future society, and EV’s are going to play a vital part in that. They can stabilise the energy grid, if powered by intermittent renewables, but it’s a transition, and the more we invest now, the sooner we can have a fully electrified society, and be carbon neutral.

This is a link to the Harvard study I'm referencing (it's more or less regurgitated by most pro EV arguments. https://www.google.com/amp/s/thedriven.io/2019/12/09/are-evs-cleaner-than-ice-coal-grid/amp/

Also noteworthy is that 150k miles is not the avg lifetime of a typical vehicle. I would argue that the people who buy an EV with 150k miles on it are not exactly able to afford new batteries to bring their vehicles back up to par regarding milage per charge. Whereas 150k miles plus ICE's still get the same milage for the most part. 

Used EVs  with >/= 150k miles on them will get substantially worse miles per charge and therefore emit substantially more carbon. Down the line this will become a huge factor as the EV ages and gets less and less miles per charge. No? These EVs will end up on the road for 300k miles as they will last longer than ICE's not less and be emitting 200% plus at that point. No one buys a high milage car intending to spend the money to make it equal to a new one efficiency wise.

David Stone Ok there’s a lot to address with what you’ve said. Number one, temperatures around the globe are down currently because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Global emissions are down for the moment, so temperatures being down isn’t surprising. Second, you’ve confused weather with climate. Weather is short term and can change based on several factors, notably seasons. Climate is long term, you don’t see its effects on a day to day basis. Climate is examined in years, sometimes decades. 

https://www.climate.gov/news-features/understanding-climate/climate-change-global-temperature

The graph shows that since the 1800’s (when the industrial revolution began and humans began significantly affecting the climate) average global temperatures have increased by nearly 2 degrees. Third, China and India do emit a significant amount of green house gases. However, the US also emits much more significantly. Additionally China actually is one of the global leaders in green technology. The reason why the United States should be the global leader in decarbonizing is because we are a developed economy that pollutes significantly. We can afford to decarbonize, unlike developing economies like India. China and India are undergoing their industrial revolutions now. So they should decarbonize as soon as they can afford to. 

What are the advantages of decarbonizing the United States? First of all our decarbonization would be significant to global emissions. Second of all it would encourage other countries to decarbonize, likely the U.K., Canada, Australia, New Zealand, EU, Japan, Taiwan, and South Korea. Third, the United States would become the leader in green solutions, creating massive economic growth. Fourth, it would allow the United States to continue to be highly influential in the world, without the need of wars. The US is still the world’s largest market, a green economy that could begin decarbonizing the world would be immensely influential to our diplomacy.

So called "clean" nuclear energy may be an effective alternative to fossil fuels as they don't really produce any CO2, but advocates of nuclear technology often overlook that the nuclear rods will have to be replaced. I agree that nuclear waste has been effectively stored and no incidences of leakage have been reported in the US, but the process of extracting nuclear material for nuclear power plants is itself unclean. The concern here is that many miners, especially those in underdeveloped countries, may not often have access to PPE or that the radioactive materials may leak into the pipes and water supply of local communities. I find that this point is often poorly addressed by nuclear advocates and that if nuclear energy is to be sustainable, it should also be sustainable on inputs.

@VeryEvilPettingZoo Ok maybe I underestimated it by a factor of 3: here are the categories that Cook et al state. I have added the numbers that Bahner found beside each.

1,Explicitly endorses and quantifies AGW as 50+% : 64
2,Explicitly endorses but does not quantify or minimize: 922
3,Implicitly endorses AGW without minimizing it: 2910
4,No Position: 7970
5,Implicitly minimizes/rejects AGW: 54
6,Explicitly minimizes/rejects AGW but does not quantify: 15
7,Explicitly minimizes/rejects AGW as less than 50%: 9

So 64 out of 11,944, or 0.5%, take the view that humans are the main cause of global warming. But that includes all abstracts, including those that did not take a position. It would be nice to take the 64 as a percent of those that did take a position. Unfortunately, in their data set, Cook et al put 4a, those that do not address the cause of global warming, with 4b, those that express the view that humans’ role in global warming is uncertain or undefined. It would be nice to separate them, but we can’t unless we have the even rawer data. So let’s generously conclude that everyone in category 4 has expressed no view. That’s a total of 7970, leaving a total of 3,974 that have expressed a view. The 64 who think the main cause is humans is, drum roll please: *1.6%*.

*1.6%* is pretty different from 97%....
0.53% of publications that express an opinion endorse the consensus? Certainly not.
