I live in New Zealand , we have just had a very hot summer. It has taught me about eco systems  , not being able to cope with the temp changes.


New Zealand is in the safest place , apart from Norway  , when talking about moving to avoid the worst.
As far as i can evaluate from the net
And what seems hot to NZ may be considered mild , in other parts of the globe.


But to all or little animals , insects , and native plants ,  "IT IS A DEATH SENTENCE"
We have some very pretty native birds , black robin , fantail , the list is huge.
These birds evolved in NZ , and were never repeated in any other location on the globe.
And already they are dying.  
 
We have the KIWI , this bird is nocturnal , so much so , that our department of conservation , has found young kiwi are starting to evolve without eyes. I think this  is only one specific type of Kiwi.


You can look for Kiwi for years and never see one, hiding a cam is about the only way we have ever been able to see them in the wild.
But this summer a woman on a bush walk , came across a KIWI out in the open.


It was a hot sunny day , and the KIWI had come into the open to drink from a stream.
The only explanation for such unseen behavior , is the kiwi was close to death  .


That is the only reason  this little nocturnal bird  , would risk coming out , or even be awake during daylight hours.
So NZ is already in big trouble.
But still no signs of any real public concern or proper awareness .
Why? , because so many people are still ok.
It seems people will do piss all , until the food crops fail , or the water fails to flow into the hose.


The hose that people use to wash their car. Yes it is water that can be drunk.
Its great water. So while Robins , Fantails , Kiwis , native plants and countless insects die from thirst , we may think its sad , but we still have to wash our cars with water . Water that would have saved countless living beings.


For years now , i only wash my vehicle , when its raining. No hose ever , and i dont use any soaps.
just a soft cloth , wiping over the car while it is raining.
Sure its certainly no fun , so what.
I have a dish washer and dont use any soap , its interesting as most times all dishes look great.


If not then clean them in a very small amount of water in the sink , and soap if needed.
It will only be a couple of items at the most. 
Always wait until dish wash is full , and make sure its lean on its water use.
A good washer will save water and using no soap is a great feeling , if you wanted to kill a living plant or animal , feed it one dish washer soap tablet , it will die.


I cut my power bills in half , turned down hot water , not to much as i like the water very hot , and replaced all bulbs with L.E.D.
Our speed limit is 100 kms , on the motorway i stick to slower lane and travel at 90 ,  i could not believe the result when i first started , it saved 20 dollars per tank.


The more you try to save the planet , the more money you have left over every week.
I have started a separate savings account  , and what i can save buy being eco aware goes into the account.


I hope to one day buy an affordable all electric car , from this account.
Then it will be free , and hope to also be able to charge it at home with solar panels on my roof.


Anyway climate change is happening right now , and i have seen it ramping up big time in the last 5 summers.
It is going to get us all , no matter where we live , and its going to be a nightmare.

The message would be , start changing to electric vehicle stations with fast charge technology.
Invest your profits into electric vehicle research and even manufacture.

At the first sign that any company like shell or Mobil are indeed hearing the message , and provocatively coming up with solutions , then the movement can advise all members to support those company's only .

“The 98% claim (from 2009) was based on a single survey by a University of Illinois professor and a graduate student. They sent a 2-minute online survey to 10,257 earth scientists. They got 3,146 responses to only these two questions…”
The first question asked, “When compared with pre-1800 levels, do you think that mean global temperatures have generally risen, fallen, or remained relatively constant?” The second asked, “Do you think that human activity is a significant contributing factor in changing mean global temperatures?”
Ninety percent of the respondents said that the mean temp had risen, while 82 percent said that human activity was a significant factor. However, the term “significant” was never defined. Furthermore, according to the Heartland Institute, most skeptic scientists would agree with the statistic if the term was defined.
The video explains that when formulating the 97 percent statistic, researchers used only the responses from “climate scientists.” However, only 5 percent of the respondents – 79 people – were climate scientists.

So, out of 10,257 academics that the professor and graduate student identified as worthy survey participants, only 79 were in agreement with their final finding. When calculated, those 79 scientists – now accepted as 97 percent - make up a meager 0.77 percent of academics. And, since only 97 percent of the 79 answered positively (which would be 76.63 people – so we will round to 77), the percentage shrinks from 0.77 percent to 0.75 percent.

The long version took months of research and comparison plus logic. This is a short version.
Note the omissions and contradictions in any model or theory. 
Note the complexity and feasibility demanded by the brief.
Climate Change model and theory fail on all counts.
Omission: no account of waste heat from Mankind’s combustion based activity.
Contradiction: CO2 and Waste heat are BOTH are the product of combustion. CO2 adds no heat, it only limits the escape of heat into Space (Green House Effect).  The Waste heat part does not appear in the Model and Theory for Global Warming. So how come CO2 from Mankind’s activities is blamed for global warming?
Complexity: Nature has determined the status quo for millennia. The available processes are myriad. Most include a feedback control mechanism. This implies that return to stability takes time. To model Nature requires long term data over many cycle of disturbance from the stable state. Nature’s mechanisms control within a set of rules and behaviour.  Conservation of Matter is a key one that requires Carbon mass in either gas, solid or liquid form to be fixed. 
Feasibility: Mankind’s activities are restricted to the inhabited surface of the Globe (about 10%) and to a massive extent to the densely populated areas. These areas are poorly distributed around the Globe. It is claimed that CO2 emissions quickly spread globally to give equal concentration.
 HOWEVER, Warming from Mankind’s activity is, as we inevitably all witness, a local phenomenon, which Nature distributes through its complex feedback processes.
Weather and Climate Theory and Models choose either CO2 (Climate) and Heat Energy (weather). Neither use both.  A composite model is not feasible. It could not meet the complexity  nor satisfy the brief.

Ok let’s take the science route... 
Science owes its success to the scientific method of investigating the universe around us. This method was described to me by my teacher as coming up with a theory of how something works, developing every possible way to try to disprove that theory, getting others involved in trying to disprove the theory and only when everyone has failed to disprove it time and time again, finally having to accept that the theory must be correct. It is this incredibly high level of scepticism that gives science its trustworthy and repeatable nature and allows us to use science to correctly predict extrapolations of existing facts into new and untested territories with a high degree of success.

So the next time someone tells you the science on something is settled and calls you a denier or a sceptic you can thank them for confirming your adherence to the core principles of science and not on faith - needed due to the fact it’s based on emotion and a total lack of facts.

We are currently in our 5th ICE age (google Quaternary glaciation if you don’t know this) and during these ice ages 70-95 percent of the earth is often covered with ice... that’s global cooling. We are in a warmer part of this period so not so bad atm. During our planets “normal” period the oceans were 152 feet above where they are now and temps around 50 deg C were common.

During previous ice ages people traveled along ocean floors to other continents - oceans got that low... 

The fossil fuels that everyone is now so worried about came from fossilised remains of living plants and animals that were living on the surface of our world during its longest and most vibrantly lush and diverse period. The carbon released burning fuels is the same carbon that was above ground for millions of years during the dinosaurs reign. 

We live on a world that is essentially a closed system. The water we drink today has been recycling through the guts of dinosaurs and plants for those same millions of years. The balance of chemicals in this planetary system are fixed with the exception of tiny amounts that get fired off into space or brought here by meteorites, or locked temporarily away by being sealed in the soil/rock by tremors or tar pits etc. but essential the carbon we have is the same carbon that existed when the earth came into existence. Only how much is in the atmosphere changes from time to time... the absolute amount that is within our system does not change much at all.

Anthropogenic Climate Change is the hypothesis that man, through his actions, is able to influence climate upon our planet. This is also the first stage of a process called terraforming. Which is the “hypothetical process of deliberately modifying a planet’s atmosphere, temperature, surface topography or ecology to be similar to the environment of Earth” so as to make it liveable for Earth creatures. The idea is to be able to manipulate the climate to be the way we want it to be and not the way nature wants it to be.

So what is the right climate? Depends on who you talk to, right?

Only human arrogance would dare believe our wants matter more than all other creatures because we currently rule.

*TOP 10 REASONS TO DOUBT CLIMATE CHANGE AKA GLOBAL WARMING*

1. Our species went through multiple ice ages and global warmings. The current global warming started approximately 12,000 years ago. That's how the last ice age ended and the current geological period, the Holocene, began. This warm and cozy climate won't last forever. Interglacial periods last between 20,000 and 60,000 years. So, we have between 8,000 and 48,000 years until the next ice age.

2. The rate at which the sea level is rising now is much lower compared to how it rose between 12,000 and 7,000 years ago – a period in which the sea level rose by 197 ft (60 m). Look up the *Early Holocene Sea Level Rise* if you want to learn more.

3. The climate is always changing. There is no such thing as a stable climate. If you want to learn more about the "stability" of the climate, you might want to look up:
– *The 8.2 Kiloyear Event*
– *The Little Ice Age*
– *The Year Without a Summer (1816)*

4. *Chaos Theory* tells us why the behavior of some systems is unpredictable (chaotic). Even simple systems can exhibit chaotic behavior, like the double pendulum, for example – https://youtu.be/U39RMUzCjiU. No one can predict the climate.

5. Computer simulations of chaotic systems have no predictive value because the initial conditions can never be measured with sufficient accuracy. Such simulations only generate pretty pictures on a screen. Again, no one can predict the behavior of chaotic systems. Because – *Chaos Theory!*

6. Compared to water, CO₂ plays an insignificant role in the global greenhouse effect. Because – and I'm not making this up – *95% of all greenhouse gases is water vapor.* 

7. CO₂ is _not_ a pollutant. CO₂ is plant food. Almost all the oxygen in the atmosphere is a byproduct of photosynthesis – a process by which plants use light energy to produce glucose from CO₂ and water. Without CO₂ plants die. Without plants, we die. CO₂ is used in the food industry, for example, in the production of carbonated beverages like: beer, soda, sparkling water etc. CO₂ is also used in hospitals, for example, in laparoscopic surgery. There are real pollutants out there we should be worried about and CO₂ is not one of them.

8. Compared to astronomical factors like solar activity or the _Milankovitch Cycles_ or terrestrial factors like volcanic activity, human activity has an insignificant effect in the long term evolution of the climate. We cannot start, end, or prevent ice ages or global warmings. We're not that significant.

9. This may came as a shock to you, but we're actually in the middle of a 2.58-million-year-old glaciation – the *Quaternary Glaciation* – look it up!

10.  There are many scientists who disagree with various aspects of anthropogenic climate change. One of them is Ivar Giaever, Nobel laureate in physics, who essentially said Global Warming is pseudoscience – https://youtu.be/TCy_UOjEir0. Freeman Dyson said that "Climate Change predictions are absurd" – https://youtu.be/fmy0tXcNTPs Wikipedia has a _List of scientists who disagree with the scientific consensus on global warming,_ but it only contains the names of those scientists "who have their own Wikipedia article." Keep in mind that science doesn't work by consensus. Science isn't a democracy. As Carl Sagan put it:

“Science is more than a body of knowledge. It is a way of thinking; a way of skeptically interrogating the universe with a fine understanding of human fallibility. If we are not able to ask skeptical questions, to interrogate those who tell us that something is true, to be skeptical of those in authority, then, we are up for grabs for the next charlatan (political or religious) who comes rambling along.”

Time for a reality check. Changes in the Earth’s orbit around the sun affects the amount of seasonal sunlight reaching the Earth’s surface. In the case of warming, the lag between temperature and CO2 is explained as follows: as ocean temperatures rise, oceans release CO2 into the atmosphere. In turn, this release amplifies the warming trend, leading to yet more CO2 being released. In other words, increasing CO2 levels become both the cause and effect of further warming. This positive feedback is necessary to trigger the shifts between glacials and interglacials as the effect of orbital changes is too weak to cause such variation.

The latest version of the "crisis" cleverly refers to "carbon" in the atmosphere - which is a pollutant, but the whole "debate" has been about CO2.  And to correct you, carbon does not go into the atmosphere and bond with oxygen to form CO2, CO2 is produced in many ways - exhaling for example. According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de Géophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15°C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. Pépin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

There’s a problem at the very beginning. There’s one world, one climate, one environment: there was absolutely no control group to rule out other causes of the findings. Second problem: the climate has changed continually for as long as we have been alive, and with what scientific tools are available to us, it appears to have been going on like that for a long time. In addition to this fact being an uncontrollable variable, it asked the question “should we be messing with the weather?.“ And that is completely aside from the fact that our ability to control the weather is a whole other variable. Who is to say that the weather modification activities that have been going on for years have not skewed results? Add to that the fact that leaders like George Bush and Kissinger etc. have been quoted as saying, or have written, That in pursuit of a one world government they need a problem big enough to draw everyone together and that climate is a great tool for that. Now you need to separate “science” with flat out human manipulation, greed etc. Then we can move a little further into the fact that there is a large body of scientists who do not agree, and who explain very clearly how the “consensus statistics” were manipulated, and how they do not dare to speak out until after retirement because they actually need to feed their families.  If the world is heating up, regardless of the cause, it seems as though we simply post the public service announcement and suggest that people crops that can tolerate more extreme weather changes, and consider selling your property if you are at a low elevation. And let people take responsibility for their decisions. That is a little glib, but I hope you get my point. Instead of promoting solutions being generated by people at the top, just let people know that it’s open season on solutions to the changes that are possibly coming. Oh, yes. There is that niggling little issue… We can’t even accurately predict the weather next week, much less next month, next year, in 12 years. But wait, there’s more: It would be nice if the people who are doing the weather manipulation would cease and desist so we can see what the weather is actually supposed to be. So far, the only thing being offered to us is shaming for questioning, and higher taxes to pay for… What, exactly?  And it’s not like using LED bulbs and Tesla cars are actually good for your health in the short one or the long run. But there are plenty of people who would like to lobby for legislation that gives them incentives to create “green“ options that may, but probably will not, “fix” the perceived problem. At our expense. So, you presented a very rational sounding video but you are missing the boat on Key pieces of the story.

Happily, as more people start realizing the nature of the threat, many will leap into action motivated by some combination of love for life and by fear and moral obligation. I'm betting that hundreds of millions of people are already taking small steps--consuming less, driving a little bit less, turning down the thermostat in winter, flying less (this is apparently a measurable trend in Sweden), eating less meat, etc. And the climate strike on September 20th was tied for the largest global protest in history. Lots of young people look at the world we older boomers gave them, and they are horrified and scared, so more of them will keep leaping into action and they will shame some others into action. For it to be fast enough to dodge 2 degree C warming, we need the trend to go viral, and need to override the greedy short-term impulses of fossil fuel companies and many billionaires. It's a heavy lift, but either we do that or Earth's ecosystems will continue to be degraded and collapse, and then our food supply, civilization, and population would collapse.  Happily, there are hundreds of strategies for cooling the Earth and healing its ecosystems, but it will take a revolution in how we think and live. 


Take care.

Wanna' know ALL the effects more CO2 and the related warming cause? As I taught one of my university classes recently, the long-term harmful effects of rapidly adding much  more CO2 include global warming of the land, atmosphere, and especially oceans; rapid and accelerating melting of the Earth’s ice sheets and glaciers, rising sea levels (very slow at first but increasingly catastrophic), growing shortages of freshwater for drinking and irrigation affecting billions of people, more intense droughts, floods, and wildfires; and more air pollution and related human health problems due to more intense forest fires.  

The overly-optimistic folks who claim that global greening from more CO2 apparently don’t know that with the greening, weeds tend to really benefit, and with the warming you get more harm to crops and forests from insects, fungi, and disease; grain crops have already lost 5-8% or more of key nutrients due to more CO2 and will continue to lose more, and the amount of sugars in grain crops will continue to rise. Lower nutrient content and higher sugar content in our foods just feeds the crisis of obesity and related diseases, driving up health care costs further. Also, more CO2 means plants will grow thicker leaves and need more water due to increased CO2 (this will intensify water shortages as 70-80% of freshwater is used for agriculture/food production). The more intense droughts and floods creates problems for many farmers, and the range where certain crops can be grown efficiently has moved towards the poles by 100 miles or more already: Unfortunately, there is less land near the poles than in the fatter middle of the Earth, and the land up there often hasn’t had time or opportunity (permafrost) to develop really rich topsoil. Thus, while more CO2 can increase crop growth at first, as warming and all the other ripple effects kick in, crops get more stressed and struggle: Thus, a recent study expects 60% of the global wheat crop to be threatened by 2100. 

More CO2 and the warming it causes also means the spread of human disease as the “tropics” and its mosquito-borne diseases expand by 30 miles a decade, while melting permafrost has unleashed other diseases long-frozen in the ice (e.g., anthrax). 

Then there’s the warming-caused mass die-offs of coral reefs and the fish and other aquatic life that depend on them, the increasing drying of America from west to east, the slowing of ocean currents with ripple effects for climate (already beginning) and increasing the size of dead zones in the ocean, the collapse of ecosystems on land (permafrost region, drying of the Amazon) and sea (decline/collapse of coral reefs and fish populations, polar ecosystem heading for collapse as “cold-enough” areas disappear), sea snails at the bottom of the food chain having their shells dissolve at much higher rates because of the more acidic oceans, other shellfish having a harder time building shells, and thus being 30-50% smaller than normal), almost all green sea turtles are now being born female (because gender is regulated by the temperature of the sand at that time of year). 

More CO2 rapid die-offs of species related to the above—including the disappearance of 40% of the plankton population since the 1950s, increasing crop failures due to the above, increasingly-worsening refugees crises due to the above, increasingly staggering mitigation and repair costs due to the above, and increasing political and social instability and violence and resource conflicts/wars (already happening) due to all of the above. The chain reactions are vastly worse than you have ever been told—truly catastrophic in the long run, leading (if we don’t take rapid action) to the collapse of ecosystems, our food supply, and our civilization and population. I don’t know, but I do know that very few scientists know all of these destructively cascading ripple effects because most don’t read much outside of their specialty. P.S. I didn’t even include all of those ripple effects.

So, if you are watching videos and reading on websites that “Hey, more CO2 is great—it’s plant food,” I want to know why aren’t these folks aren’t telling you the WHOLE story? Why are they only telling you about 1% of the changes rapidly increasing CO2 levels will cause, and leaving out the other 99%.  Is it because they don’t know the whole story? That may be  understandable—I only know all this because I’ve been researching for more than 10 years on a book about what we need to do to protect and heal society and the planet. With all due respect, I believe you are not looking at the big picture and how all the parts of the system interact. Yes, in a controlled experiment in a greenhouse, more CO2 gets you more plant growth. That part you have right. But that experiment doesn't reflect the real-world ripple effects of global increases in CO2, meaning those experiments are useless for guiding policy. So how do natural systems actually work? In the real world, increased CO2 is causing global warming which in turn causes the atmosphere to hold more water (7% more for every 1 degree C increase in temperature), which is leading to the drying out of ecosystems--for example, across the American west. The combination of warming and drier soils than has allowed for things like the beetle infestations in the Rockies. The combination of these factors has led to staggering die offs of forests, for example, 
>800 million "standing dead" trees in Colorado alone. This increase in dead trees makes forest fires worse, releasing even more CO2 into the atmosphere, thus causing even more warming and an acceleration of this kind of destruction. The dried out ground also releases more CO2, and the whole cycle leads to epic storms, floods, and droughts. Meanwhile, the warming has already made crops such as grains to have 5-8% less of key nutrients, thus promoting poor human health, overeating, or both. More broadly, pumping most of that heat and EXCESS CO2 human pumped into the atmosphere was absorbed by the oceans, making them warmer and 30% more acidic. Marine life isn't designed for these rapid changes in their ecosystem, and the last time the Earth warmed this rapidly, >90% of life in the oceans went extinct. THAT is where our reckless disruption of ecosystem balance is taking us: For example, half of the largest living thing on Earth--the 2400 mile-long Great Barrier Reef--already died in two events related to global warming and ocean acidification. Unless we reverse the damage we have done, virtually all or all coral reefs (the rainforests of the ocean) will be extinct by 2100. We are literally killing the oceans in a very direct way. 

Humans and all other living things on Earth evolved in an Earth that kept within a narrow range of average temperatures and with rather stable climate, and by pushing the system outside those parameters, we are setting in motion the "Sixth Extinction" of life on Earth. Not only does this mean killing off much of what we love about the natural world, human civilization is totally dependent of the health of the Earth's ecosystems, so unless we turn things around rapidly, humanity will witness in my children's lifetimes hundreds of millions to billions of human deaths due to our warming of the planet and destruction of the biosphere.

It's hard to face, but those ARE the facts on the ground.

With all due respect, I believe you are not looking at the big picture and how all the parts of the system interact. Yes, in a controlled experiment in a greenhouse, more CO2 gets you more plant growth. That part you have right. But that experiment doesn't reflect the real-world ripple effects of global increases in CO2, meaning those experiments are useless for guiding policy. So how do natural systems actually work? In the real world, increased CO2 is causing global warming which in turn causes the atmosphere to hold more water (7% more for every 1 degree C increase in temperature), which is leading to the drying out of ecosystems--for example, across the American west. The combination of warming and drier soils than has allowed for things like the beetle infestations in the Rockies. The combination of these factors has led to staggering die offs of forests, for example, 
>800 million "standing dead" trees in Colorado alone. This increase in dead trees makes forest fires worse, releasing even more CO2 into the atmosphere, thus causing even more warming and an acceleration of this kind of destruction. The dried out ground also releases more CO2, and the whole cycle leads to epic storms, floods, and droughts. Meanwhile, the warming has already made crops such as grains to have 5-8% less of key nutrients, thus promoting poor human health, overeating, or both. More broadly, pumping most of that heat and EXCESS CO2 human pumped into the atmosphere was absorbed by the oceans, making them warmer and 30% more acidic. Marine life isn't designed for these rapid changes in their ecosystem, and the last time the Earth warmed this rapidly, >90% of life in the oceans went extinct. THAT is where our reckless disruption of ecosystem balance is taking us: For example, half of the largest living thing on Earth--the 2400 mile-long Great Barrier Reef--already died in two events related to global warming and ocean acidification. Unless we reverse the damage we have done, virtually all or all coral reefs (the rainforests of the ocean) will be extinct by 2100. We are literally killing the oceans in a very direct way. 

Humans and all other living things on Earth evolved in an Earth that kept within a narrow range of average temperatures and with rather stable climate, and by pushing the system outside those parameters, we are setting in motion the "Sixth Extinction" of life on Earth. Not only does this mean killing off much of what we love about the natural world, human civilization is totally dependent of the health of the Earth's ecosystems, so unless we turn things around rapidly, humanity will witness in my children's lifetimes hundreds of millions to billions of human deaths due to our warming of the planet and destruction of the biosphere.

It's hard to face, but those ARE the facts on the ground. 

Take care.

Have you seen the data on how high C02 strips staple crops of their natural defenses against insects? Have you seen the EPA stats showing increasing epic rainstorms since 1958, which wash away topsoil and fertilizer and decimate plants? How about the increasing severity of droughts? The C02-plant equation is not nearly as simple as the oil industry-funded blogs would have you believe. The consensus among scientists is that while C02 can clearly make plants more lush, the C02-warming problem and its side effects more than wipe out any benefits.

Why do you think sun activity (like the Maunder Minimum) is important for the warming trend of the last couple of decades, when it doesn't even correlate with global temperature? Since the 80s, sun activity has decreased while global temperature kept increasing. So I think it's save to say that _nowadays_ sun activity is clearly not the main driver of global warming!
Also, the medieval warm period is much overrated by climate deniers (or sceptic or whatever you'd like to be labelled). Sure, it had natural causes such as changes in ocean currents, decreased volcanic activity and also sun activity, but it was mainly limited to parts of the Northern Hemisphere. And when looking instead at the *global* temperature during that time of the MWP, it was considerably colder than the global temperature of the previous 50 years.

That, right there, is the exact reason why I didn't understand climate change, that part is almost always oversimplified. Why would the atmosphere let radiation enter but not leave? Well, it's very simple: greenhouse gases are (mostly) transparent to light and UV rays, that hit the ground and heat it up. The ground is constantly cooling down by emitting infrared radiation that would usually leave Earth, but since greenhouse gases are opaque to infrared light, it heats up the atmosphere. If we continue releasing greenhouse gases or remove the plants that get rid of the excess, we'll all cook to death.

It is interesting to hear people who know absolutely nothing about science pontificate on the subject. The biggest lie about climate change is, "The science is settled". Real science is NEVER settled and every true scientist will tell you that. It is a never ending process and we only ever have a view of an intermediate step. The flat earthers were proven wrong. Sir Isaac Newton, one of the greatest names in science, was proven wrong. Einstein, who's name is all but synonymous with genius was proven wrong. And so have or will all the rest who call themselves scientists be proven wrong, sooner or later. There are always errors in every scientific theory and later theories will overtake them. Laws of science are just well tested theories and they also topple in the face of new facts. 



I do not claim to know what the world's climate will do in the future. I do know it has managed to stumble along without our "help" for billions of years. I suspect it will continue to do so. 



By the way, just how many of the global climate alarmists are not being financed by government funding? Funding that is dolled out ONLY to "scientists" who can be depended on to claim there is cause for alarm. And why have these "scientists" adjusted the data to conform with their preconceived theories? The answer is obvious: the true data, without those arbitrary adjustments does not. It, in fact, clearly shows no real climate change. 



In case you don't see the above process: Rich Financial People finance politicians / politicians are elected / elected representatives appoint leaders in government agencies / government agencies provide funding for scientific research / and that scientific research provides the "evidence" for climate change that the Rich Financial People want. And researchers who do not go along with that are NOT FUNDED. But many non-funded scientists DO look at the climate and the "evidence" provided by those funded ones and just shake their heads. It's a plot all right, just not the one you think. 



It is not the coal and oil companies who are trying to make a killing here. It is the companies who want to develop the grossly inefficient alternate energy sources. They know they can not compete with traditional energy so they want to "level" the playing field with my money and yours. They are taking tax payer money to develop energy sources that will cost those same tax payers more when they use them. AND because those alternate energy sources are really more expensive, they also USE more of our resources so they are the total opposite of "green". They gobble up our resources instead of saving them. On that basis along, they should be totally banned, but I do not like the government calling the shots. We simply should NOT subsidise them and just let them compete with the present energy sources while standing on their own feet. No government, no tax payer help ever. Let the free market decide if they are better. Yes, based on price. Price is an excellent way to judge just how "green" something is. In fact, it is probably the only way to quantify just how "green" something is. Higher price equals more resources expended and therefore, equates with less "green". It really is common sense. Not some "guilt trip" that has been manufactured just to help some new companies that will make these expensive and NON-GREEN technologies and make THEIR investors rich in the process.

​@zorblin - 
_"weather reporting has been improving drastically,"_
*True, but this is due to nothing more than satellites and the ability to literally watch storm systems in real-time.  They are still just as baffled as ever when a freak storm pops up out of nowhere.*
_"climate models have been able to reproduce past data, and have made predictions that have been confirmed."_
*That is a deceptive statement.  Can they tweak a model to coax out the desired result?  Sure, but when they feed in the next data set they have to start re-tweaking all over again.  If your equations and algorithms need to be altered every time you change data sets...  your model is worthless.*
_"This leads to an imbalance of CO2,"_
*I do not believe CO2 is remotely capable of controlling the climate to the levels proclaimed by the alarmists.  I believe it was selected because it can be tied directly to humans.  Even if CO2 WERE capable of controlling the climate, I have yet to hear a single expert identify the #1 cause--BY FAR--of atmospheric CO2 and CH4...  and it's NOT HUMANS.  It's a process involving earthquakes and microbes, and we don't hear about it because THE EXPERTS ARE CLUELESS.  This is a glaring indication that the supposed experts DO NOT TRULY UNDERSTAND all that they claim to understand, and it's a huge red flag that we should investigate much more fully before passing sweeping legislation that will be devastating to all but the wealthy elite.*

If the evidence supported an end to civilization without going this route..  then we do what we've gotta do.  But the evidence says that this is a scheme..  and we CANNOT GO GENTLY INTO THAT  GOOD NIGHT.*

@freemind You are completely strawmanning, let's have a quality discourse. Weather IS NOT CLIMATE. Climate is _in general_, while weather is very specific. The reason weather is hard to predict, is the sheer amount of variables. Furthermore, weather reporting has been improving drastically, and climate models have been able to reproduce past data, and have made predictions that have been confirmed. It's not about the prediction, it's about the science. So, take CO2. When an infrared photon hits the molecule, it vibrates, due to the energy. Afterwards, it vibrates again, releasing an infrared photon. This is caused by the CO2 molecule having 3 or more atoms, leading to complex vibration modes that allow them to interact with IR photons/waves. Secondly, human CO2 emission has been coinciding along with the natural trapping of CO2 in sinks such as plants, or the oceans. This leads to an imbalance of CO2, as before the industrial revolution, the amount of CO2 emitted by humans was able to be absorbed by natural carbon sinks. But now, we exceed the amount of possible absorbance, leading to an increase in CO2.

The "biggest lie" about climate change IS Climate Change... and the [pretense] of looming catastrophic planetary changes.

Earth's climate is remarkably stable in reality, and there is absolutely no chance of any "runaway warming" or catastrophic changes due to mankind's energy production; the math isn't there; the science isn't there; computer models are not reality.

Without some outside cosmic influence or unknown subcrustal, deep core event occurring in our planet, there is not enough sequestered carbon to disrupt the climate; the energy isn't there; the amount of releasable carbon is not significant; carbon absorbs only so much energy and the rest is radiated out into space; the "sponge effect" trumps the "greenhouse effect"- and the effects are measurable, and prove the Iris Effect right; no hot spot in tropics; decreasing "warming per PPM" per doubling of CO2; at most 1.5°C for 600ppm, then 0.7° for 1200ppm, then MAYBE 0.4° for 2400ppm and it would literally take millions of years for that to happen...

Again, barring any sort of additional energy bombarding us from space; CO2 just cannot store energy forever, so the greenhouse effect is more effected by water vapor and other trace gases.

That is what the science really says; like it or not; there is no looming catastrophe; climate indeed changes; life adapts; we adapt.

It is really difficult to take anything scientists say seriously. How many of us remember the global cooling scare of the 1970s? Probably not many, because it has been swept under the rug. Here are a few headlines from that period: “International team of specialists finds no end in sight to 30 year cooling trend in northern hemisphere“. The New York Times, January 5, 1978. “Colder winters herald dawn of new Ice Age“. The Washington post January 11, 1970. “New Ice Age coming – it’s already getting colder“. Los Angeles times, October 24, 1971. I could go on but you get the general idea. Now we are told that the ice caps are melting, the oceans are rising, the earth’s temperature is rising as well. How many people know that during the early Triassic period, It rained for 2 million years?! @Baguette Gott - You are correct in your assertion that the atmosphere prevents most meteorites ever impacting the Earth at all.  However, that only applies to objects the size of a grain of sand---up to maybe the size of your fist.  Thankfully that covers the majority of potential impactors.  The larger meteorites..  of the Extinction Level Event variety would not be burned up in or even slowed by the Earth's atmosphere.  Therefore I think it's important to make people aware that the fear-mongering is based on fallacious propaganda.  Once it is commonly understood how few of the craters are actually due to impact, people will have one less major stress-point to manage.  We all have enough to worry about without adding fabricated boogeymen to the mix.  

Most alarmism is rooted in ignorance, and is utilized as a weapon against a trusting populous to gain power, money and support for otherwise unpopular politics.  We can't rule out a civilization-ending meteor impact, super-volcano eruption, climate disaster or invasion by hostile aliens, but it's nice to know that the threat is only minimal.

@freemind The important thing is that there's not really a place in this universe where you're safe from meteorites. In the history of mankind, 50% of all carbon released into the atmosphere occurred in the last 30 years. Indeed, 
the last time there was this much carbon dioxide (CO2) in the Earth's atmosphere, modern humans didn't exist. The burning of fossil fuels and the chemical-intensive industrial agriculture are the main drivers of climate change. The good news is that humans have the power to stop, and potentially reverse, climate change, but the solution is not fancy new carbon-capturing technology (biochar is the way to go as far as sequestration goes / it would also reduce the use of artificial fertilizer production and nitrous oxide emissions). A significant part of the solution to climate change is to harness the power of Mother Nature. Harnessing the energy of earth (geothermal), water (hydroelectric), air (wind generators) and sun (solar cells and collectors) and, also, in the form of organic regenerative agriculture and the restoration of forests, peatlands, mangroves and other ecosystem habitats capable of drawing down and storing excess atmospheric carbon.

Ok lets get this straight. Climate change is something that happens naturally in an ecosystem as large as own. Throughout the many million of years prior to us humans being on this planet, there have been major fluctuations in temperature and C02 levels in the atmosphere that this "climate change" debate can be deemed as completely down to the long term natural variations in the earth's climate. In the age of the dinosaurs, they were able to exist due to the much higher C02 levels. The mega flora was able to exist due to these high C02 levels. Change in climate is completely down to how the earth changes in its position around the sun and on its axis. With the attention on melting ice caps, it has been proven that the water re-freezes on the opposite side of the globe where it is colder. The variations in temperature are down to less than a degree which is once again completely down to the natural variation in our earth's climate. On studies of some mountains that are near the area in which I live, over the past decade or so the levels of snow have been gradually rising each winter. Record cold temperatures are indeed being reached, it is just covered up by those who are so set on climate change being the "impending doom of humanity". In the past the planet has had many ice ages as many are aware of. These ice ages at some point melt with the gradual re heating of the earths atmosphere. Atmospheric change is something that has happened in the past and is now happening again. Everyone who wants to bang on about how we are destroying the planet needs to stop for a second and actually take the time to educate themselves on how it is normal for an environment as complex and diverse as our own, there will be change in its characteristics over long periods of time. Give it a few hundred years and we will be seeing ourselves in a global cooling period and the process will repeat itself. I do enjoy the videos you make, however I do believe your view on climate change is bias and you are not open to look at the natural explanations for the change in our climate.

The climate models have never successfully predicted observed climate, and objective science simply does not support the predictions of the models... namely that CO2 is a primary forcing agent of temperature.  The correlation is non-existent (except in the make believe mathematics of the models).  It's well known that CO2's warming effect rapidly diminishes as more is added to the atmosphere, and water vapor by far is the most abundant greenhouse gas.  CO2 is not a pollutant, it's essential for life.  Plants need 3 things to grow: sunlight/water/CO2... aka photosynthesis.  Most plants evolved during periods of significantly higher levels of CO2, as much as 5 times higher.  Each human emits about 800 pounds of CO2 every year simply by breathing.  After 150 years of all natural CO2 emissions (oceans/plants/animals/humans/volcanoes) plus CO2 from converting hydrocarbons to energy...  of every ten thousand molecules of atmosphere, only 4 are CO2.  Even the IPCC acknowledges the claim of "extreme weather" due to CO2 has no empirical support. The climate faithful understand so little of their own religion, yet cling with vigor to the belief their religion is somehow science.  On the other hand, people who practice one of the other major religions never mistake their religion for science, or vice-versa... it's a phenomenon unique to the climate faithful.

Of course climate change is real. However we live in a world of 71/2 billion people going up to 9-10 billion by 2050. All of which will demand more energy for a higher standard of living. But energy also must be predictable, reliable, and as concentrated as possible. This is where renewable fail. While renewables will make a significant contribution to our energy mix and help lift the worlds poorest living in remote areas out of abject poverty they can't power an advanced industrial civilization with that many people. Nuclear energy has the potential to power our industrial civilization without any carbon emissions. I would argue it can become the most environmentally friendly, safest, and cheapest source of electricity. But we aren't there yet and won't be for a while. So for now we are stuck with fossil fuels. Fossil fuels are also particularly well suited for many applications such as aviation, heavy construction and farm machinery,  and transportation in general. So where does that leave us? Basically with acceptance of climate change, and the need for mitigation and remediation of the damage that will be caused by the rise in temperatures. Climate change is here and growing, accept it, we can't reverse it, and probably not even slow it significantly. Were fooling ourselves to think so.

we are at roughly 400ppm co2 in the atmosphere, would we go below 280 ppm then we are going to die, not just us but all life on earth because photosynthesis ceases to function. the other extinction level event because of high co2 was at roughly 8000ppm. this tells us that we are 7600 ppm from death if we go upwards and 120 ppm from death if we go downwards. historically we have been at 8000ppm and survived and I'm taking my chances there and having only gone up roughly 13ppm, new designs and a lot of energy based technique and motors being developed. we are not going to reach 8000ppm, what we might reach though depending on the very many different natural systems we have on earth which lowers co2 is something lower, and we are very close to extinction. Apparently way back when they realized that importing oil to heat ther homes was too costly so they took the time and money in finding a solution that worked for them. There scientists realized that they could make there country's unique geography (aka volcanoes) work for them. Now all homes are heated with geothermal energy. Along with hydropower, they have become 100% renewable.

Now I understand that not every country has volcanoes but they can take what they have. Brazil has many rivers intersecting their country. Alot of their power comes from hydroelectric. If you want a USA example, Texas does ~20% of their electricity from Solar and Wind.

It's time to change the conversation. Stop talking about reducing greenhouse gases and talk about investing in renewable energy.

So so so so so much misinformation in this video all I can do is facepalm.

Look, I'm 40.  They've been pushing climate change since at least around the time I was born.  They said back in 1989 that if we don't do something in 10 years we're doomed, the ice caps will melt, food will be sparse, etc etc.  Well 10 years goes by and then another 20 years on top of that and things aren't any different.  Now it's "if we don't do something in 12 years we're doomed".  How many predictions of doom do we have to go through that don't even come within a nuts hair of coming true before we finally say, "hey, these guys really don't know what they are talking about"?  I can promise you 12 years will come and go and nothing will be that different.  In fact, I'm willing to put on record that ice caps will grow and it will get colder.  Hell, it's already happening.  We've seen snow in the Arizona deserts.  MASSIVE snow falls in the mountains.  Utah has received almost 200% of it's typical snowfall this year.  The midwest had snow on May 10 last year.  There was basically no spring.  Winter extended much longer and it broke immediately to a mild summer.  

Sure, it's gotten a LITTLE warmer over the last couple decades, but nothing outside of natural variability.  Ice caps are still there.  In fact the Arctic is growing, slightly.  Antarctica was at an all time maximum in 2014.  Nobody ever talks about that though because it doesn't fit the narrative.  The Arctic was reduced by the same amount if not more during the 1930's and 40's, then grew back during the 60's and early 70's.  There are way more days recorded in the 30's and 40's over 90 degrees, 95 degrees and 100 degrees than the past 2 decades combined and doubled.  It's mostly a lie folks.  Yes we do cause some warming, but we don't have a clue how much and the more we study, the less it appears we do.  Exxon scientists were not 100% sure of anything.  They believed it because they started doing the study right out of a dip in our climate and when they saw warming in correlation with the C02 output they said, yep we're doing it.  However, the understanding of our sun, cosmic rays etc and how they affect cloud cover etc, was not understood at all during that time, as well as a myriad of other things that effect the climate.  The science wasn't there for them to be able to understand exactly what was happening.  IN FACT 30 years later we still don't have the science to understand everything.  The IPCC even admits to that.  

I want to pose a question to you and you tell me what is more likely.

A group of companies KNOW we are destroying our planet and chose to hide these facts in pursuit of short term monetary gain but causing absolute doom to it's company and all the people/animals/planet

OR

A group of people are making up fake claims of doom for political/monetary gain, KNOWING full well there's not immediate doom but also know they can get a power grab in this way?

Before anyone starts saying "yeah right, 97% of scientists are all in on a scam, your so full of it"  know this.  That 97% claim is bogus.  That number was reached by scouring papers that talked about global warming.  Out of those they only included papers that gave a position on whether or not it was man made.  Out of all the papers scanned, only about 36% of the papers took a position.  OF that 36%, 97% said it was caused by humans, BUT they didn't say how much.  It ranged from very little cause to totally caused.  64% of the papers took no position, but they claim 97% agree.  Total garbage.  A actual more recent poll was done of 1,821 meteorologists and only 52% claimed it's caused by man.  Only 37% of those that actually do weather predictions claimed man is the cause.  So as you can see, there is NO consensus.  It is very much a topic in debate.

So, a couple things.  1, science isn't a consensus.  If 100 mathematicians say 2 cubed is 6 but one says it's 8, does the consensus mean that math is wrong?  Obviously not.  2, the climate is always changing.  Like since the beginning of time.  And if human actions effect it, then so does literally everything else.  The act of being on the planet means you're effecting the climate.  3, even if the US went 100% carbon negative, we still would not be able to stop the rise of CO2 in the atmosphere.  4, the greenhouse effect that has been calculated is rumored to have been arrived at using flat Earth physics and grossly overestimates the effect on the atmosphere.  5, the majority of the weather and the climate is determined by the interaction between the two most abundant fluids on the planet: water and air.  Trying to predict the results of that is like trying to balance a pencil on it's tip.  And lastly, the very people who are dedicated to observing and predicting the weather (it's kinda like a climate slice) can't even get their predictions right a week in advance or even get it near correct with live data!  Add that on top of the fact that every (literally every single one!) climate disaster prediction has not only been markedly false, but nowhere near accurate.  I've been fed the lie of climate doom since the day I was born.  Now, 30 years later, I can see that on the grander scale NOTHING HAS CHANGED!

The Sun transmits at an effective temperature of approximately 5800 K, with an emission spectrum, peaked in the central, yellow-green part of the visible spectrum.  Entering Earth's atmosphere, about 55% of the incoming sunlight is infrared photons. They strike the Earth and are reradiated back out into the atmosphere in the black body temperature range of 255K. The other 45% is white light and of that, about 30% of that is reflected back into outer space, which is what you would see from outer space looking back at the Earth. That should leave about 31.5% of the total light being white, to strike the Earth and be reradiated back into the atmosphere as infrared photons. That would mean 55% infrared photons coming in and 86.5% total infrared photons going out. As we increase secondary greenhouse gases in the atmosphere,  we block more incoming infrared photons, slightly cooling off the planet.  Being there are more outgoing infrared photons than incoming, we should trap more outgoing infrared photons than reflect incoming photons. That being said, all things being equal, the planet must heat.

Exxon didn't discover climate change. It had been bandied about since the 50s. The principals behind it had been understood since the 1800s. It was always understood that industrial output would change the climate, it just wasn't clear weather or not light reflecting particulates would have a stronger forcing effect than green-house and carbon-gases. It was in the 50s that ~most~ people who specialized in the field of studying industrial outputs effects began to understand that carbon-gasses would have a MUCH stronger forcing effect and that the world would heat. ExXon merely confirmed this information for themselves, it wasn't new information, it just wasn't well known to the public.

Gosh, that wasn't quite so hard to put the pieces together now, was it?

In 1827 Jean_Baptiste Fourier first recognized the warming effect of greenhouse gases.

In 1859, John Tyndall did the original research on the physical properties of CO2.


The first quantitative estimate of the effect of doubling atmospheric CO2 on the mean surface temperature of the Earth was made by Svante Arrhenius in 1896.  

Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences
 "Thermal Equilibrium of the Atmosphere with a given Distribution of Relative Humidity." May, 1967
Manabe and Wetherald were the first to include all the main physical processes relevant to the problem, using a model that was no more complicated than necessary to achieve this. This led to much more realistic simulations and enabled the results to be explained in terms of processes which could be observed in the real world. 
Manabe and Wetherald made a number of other discoveries. First, that the temperature of the stratosphere cooled markedly when carbon dioxide was doubled. This is the characteristic “fingerprint” of increasing carbon dioxide: the troposphere warms and the stratosphere cools, as we have observed over the last 50 years. 


0469%281967%29024%3C0241%3ATEOTAW%3E2.0.CO%3B2 https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-

Let us now talk about the multiplier effect. If we build breeder reactors first and use that electricity to produce solar panels, the BTU multiplier effect would be 2000*9=18,000 to 1. Considering a coal-fired power plant has a ratio of about 80 to 1, that figures out to be about 18,000/80=225 times the increase in efficiency. Doing so would flatten out the hierarchies of the world, creating vastly greater independence worldwide. This would accomplish exactly what the murderous communists attempted but badly failed at.

Since there seems to be an issue with fossil fuels, the question is what to do about it. This is my answer. If anyone has a different solution, I'd like to hear it. Let's begin with BTUs out vs BTU in by the energy source.

As you can see LFTRs and TWRs are the most cost efficient and safest energy supply possible at this time. We should easily be able to reach $0.02 to $0.03 per kilowatt-hour. That brings the price of everything down substantially. Building small mass-produced modular breeder reactors would also make windmills and solar panels exceptionally cost-effective. We could have the population producing the majority of their own energy leaving nuclear energy for industry. Or we can continue with this absurd global warming debate.

As the atmosphere warms, the differential temperature decreases between the ocean's surface and the atmosphere, blocking the ocean from releasing its heat.  In addition, about half of the 37 gigatonnes of CO2 is going into the oceans, also blocking the infrared heat from escaping the oceans and preventing the atmosphere from warming as much as expected.  This is where 93% of the additional heat is being stored. This additional heat in the oceans will not only ­melt the ice caps but will allow vastly larger hurricanes to form and travel at much greater distances.  The imminent threat isn't sea level rise but a future of massive storm surges. This website gives a more detailed explanation.

My only issue is that there's only really a consensus when you ignore the papers on climate change that were uncertain. ~12k papers on climate change were looked at, and ~7.9k had no opinion, or were uncertain. So it's less of a scientific consensus, and more like 2/3 of all engineers shrugging their shoulders when asked if the bridge was going to collapse, or not.

Among the 97% who took the stance that man-made climate change is real, 2910 out of the 3974 said that man is causing less than 50% of the warming. Which is more like 73% of engineers thinking the bridge will collapse just from natural causes

It doesn't change that we still need renewable energy for the sake of having an energy source for if we manage to burn through all of our oil, though. It's just that ignoring a few massive details like this feels disingenuous, and calls into question everything else that's used to prove man-made climate change. Especially when scientists at NASA have been told to fall in line with the scientific consensus to avoid any "PR Headaches," that they would have to deal with.

In the end, there are climate change deniers, because how shadily some of the data is handled, and used. Misuse of information, and influence to force a scientific consensus, rather than allowing that consensus to form naturally will cause push back no matter what side you're pulling for.

Chip Knows Nature isn’t putting out CO2. It’s already out there. We take sequestered carbon and burn it, adding to the total CO2. Yes, we put out less new CO2 each year than is already in the atmosphere. Thank goodness. Imagine if we put out enough CO2 to double the total amount every year. We would recreate Venus very quickly. Over the last 70 years, we have increased the CO2 levels from 250 parts per million to around 425 parts per million. We will have doubled the total in less than 100 years. We know the current levels are higher than any time in the last 800,000 years. How? We can measure the atmosphere captured in tiny air bubbles that long ago. Every measurement shows a much lower amount of CO2 than we measure now.

Facts!!
The flu isn’t really that deadly

A few reasons, but first it should be noted that in most of the world, flu vaccines are available to protect against the flu.


Getting beyond that, the biggest problem is that the flu isn't a single sickness caused by a single bug. "The" flu virus is actually a collection of many different kinds of virus, each of which is capable of evolving quickly thanks to its simple structure. Because of this, being immune to a single one of them is virtually no protection at all. Instead, scientists try to predict each year what flu strains are going to be the most prevalent and the most dangerous, then advise the creation of vaccines which protect against those strains. The first reason that it's so hard to vaccinate against the flu is this: if we are wrong about which strains to protect against, the vaccines offer no protection, and even if we're right there's still a good chance that a few other strains of flu will be going around.


But that's not all. Many people are a little confused about how vaccines work exactly, so I'll break it down here. Vaccines generally have three parts: the antigen, which is the sickness-causing agent (in this case the flu virus); a chemical bath designed to kill or weaken the antigen; and a substance or two designed to irritate the body just enough to hasten an immune response. Once the immune system mounts a response, it will be able to fight off the antigen, and in so doing your system will "remember" that this particular antigen is a bad thing that should be fought as soon as it is found in the body, and it will have a better ability to do so. There are four places this can go wrong, each of which is its own reason why flu vaccines are so hard, but these reasons also apply to other vaccines in most cases:
1. It takes time for the vaccine to take effect. If the patient is infected after getting vaccinated but before the vaccine takes effect, the vaccine will not be able to protect them.
2. Vaccines are preventative, they are not a cure. If a patient is infected before being vaccinated, the vaccine will not lessen the sickness.
3. The antigens in vaccines can, very rarely, cause the very disease they are meant to protect against. This is becoming less common as time goes on, and for many vaccines it simply isn't possible because the antigens used aren't even alive, but in other vaccines it is still a small possibility. Typically a disease caused in this manner is less intense and shorter than the full disease, because the antigens used are weakened.
4. Vaccines are not guaranteed to work. While they are usually effective, there are cases where a vaccinated person is still vulnerable to the disease, or has only partial protection.


Each of these four problems is made worse by the many kinds of flu virus. People who get vaccinated might think they're protected, but they aren't until the vaccine takes effect, which can take time. Because the flu is so common, they could easily get infected while going about their day, thinking they're protected when the vaccine hasn't had enough time to work yet. Or perhaps they were infected before getting the vaccine, and just haven't started showing symptoms yet. Flu vaccines need to be produced quickly once it is determined which strains should be included, so there's less time to figure out how to lower the chance that the vaccine causes the flu while still being an effective treatment.

A lot of this makes it sound like vaccines aren't that great, but on the whole, they definitely are. Still, they aren't perfect. I fully recommend vaccinating against everything we can, but I'm also not going to pretend that they're 100% safe and 100% effective because no treatment is. Still, vaccines are very close to that golden 100%, if less so for the flu in particular.

Alright, fine. The sun's influence on the climate is pretty simple:
1. Areas which get more direct sunlight will be warmer and more temperate than areas which get less. This is why areas near the equator are warmer on average than other places.
2. The sun provides the earth as a whole with energy, both in heat and light.
3. The energy from the sun can be trapped within the earth's atmosphere by greenhouse gases, such as CO2, which drastically increases the amount of heat retained in our climate.


That's pretty much all you need to know about the sun's effect on climate.

Remember, Hawking was a theoretical physicist who dealt mostly with astronomical objects, particle theory, and the nature of space-time. He was not a climate scientist, and not a social researcher. There is no climate model that has Earth uninhabitable a hundred years from now, barring a major meteor impact, or perhaps a detonation of all of the extant nuclear weapons at once. This isn't to say that there isn't a problem to be dealt with, but there's quite a difference between "dangerous storms, droughts, and famine" and "literally uninhabitable we have to leave the planet". Indeed, consider that anywhere else we went would require, in the short term, self-contained life-support stations, and in the long term, massive terraforming efforts; both of which could be much more sensibly put to use right here, with improved life-support systems for riding out severe weather, and ultimately the reversal of climate change and active control of our environment. Between adding an atmosphere to Mars and keeping Earth's atmosphere stable, I think the latter is a much more reasonable goal.

Exxon's scientists back in the 1970's may very well have believed that humans were causing the climate to change, much the same way that many scientists do today.  It's consequently a fair question to ask why Exxon would then continue to drill-baby-drill.  The answer seems clear enough - the naked pursuit of profit - BUT neither Exxon's scientists' belief in AGW then nor scientists' belief now constitute the necessary proof to resolve the matter as 'settled science'.  Then, as now, AGW was a theory.  Then, as now, there was no empirically verifiable proof that human causes are heating up the planet.  Then, as now, the earth's climate was a system so complex as to defy any capacity to accurately model it over any extended period of time.  As such, then, as now, AGW remains an unproven THEORY.  The best climate models today running on the most powerful supercomputers can't consistently correlate CO2 emissions to observed climate behavior (specifically, no models forecast 'the pause').

Bottom line..  Exxon may indeed have covered up their scientists' theories about fossil fuel emissions and the earth's climate.  A pox on their house for doing so.  But those opinions do not prove - any more than today's climate scientists' opinions do - that AGW is definitively, predictably occurring.


And environmentalists only sow more skepticism with their repeated sky-is-falling bleats that the time for debate and discussion is over.  Until climate models can actually  start successfully modeling AGW the need for debate and discussion is more important than ever.  George Carlin has it right..

Alternative power sources are available, but if they're not utilized on a far more vast scale than we have, we'll die well before we extract all the oil and gas the world has to offer. Not just because of climate change of course. We might manage to thoroughly drain all our *current* reserves of fossil fuels, but there are others that we haven't touched yet. The fossil fuel industry has a grand history of convincing governments to let them extract resources from more and more places, using methods that are less and less environmentally sound. And hey, we do need that energy right now, but maybe we wouldn't if we had invested in renewable energy.


But just for the sake of argument let's assume that humans can muddle by without any drastic drop in population until we do extract pretty much all the fossil fuels the planet has to offer. There are two possibilities from there. First, we have enough alternative energy sources to prevent widespread problems, but there will be power shortages until we can fully replace those fossil fuels with greater renewable energy infrastructure. The other option is if we don't have enough alternative energy, in which case... Well, not to put too fine a point on it, but we're looking at an apocalypse scenario. Humanity itself might survive, but the vast majority of it will be unable to continue without that energy.

I don’t mean to unceremoniously burst the ideological bubble that this video appeals to, but I must say that this is a rather gross mischaracterization of the conservative position on climate change. 

One of the points that asapscience reiterated is the lack of “debate” on this issue. This is mostly correct, but generally misleading. Yes, there is certainly no debate among the scientific community that climate change is real and worsening. Contrary to what this video might convey, most in the Republican Party would agree with this assessment. 

The “debate” does still exist with regards to both the imminence of the threat and the optimal course of action to address it. The IPCC itself projects rising seal levels to occur over the next 100 years, while others in the scientific community predict it to happen sooner. That certainly sounds like debate to me.

In another way, the “debate” is also focused on what to do about it. Is the government of the United States the best facilitator of emission reductions? Or are private, non-profit institutions? If the government has a role (which it certainly does) how big of a role does it play? Will enough everyday Americans pressure business to change environmentally unfriendly practices without the need for a government mandate to do so? Should the onus be put more heavily on developing nations, who constitute the overwhelming majority of harmful emissions production, to modernize their energy sectors? These are the questions that Republicans are asking. It is not denial of the issue of climate change. 

I am not excusing the negligent behavior of companies like Exxon or their profit-driven cognitive dissonance. Nor am I excusing any individual politician in the Republican Party who has willfully denied the existence of climate change over the years. I’d just rather not caricature half of the American electorate as ignorant or as harborers of malevolent intent. Instead, let’s engage in the debate that still exists, and use the fruits of that debate to inform both our personal actions and our votes. Maybe the answer lies in the collective ingenuity of the human race, and not solely in the hands of a government bureaucrat.
