sargeantsimon1 Firstly, none of the previous videos had, as far as I’m aware, had the owner talking into the video, which is more than 50% of this video & the owner literally adds that this isn’t their normal type of video at the end of the video. This video style is more in line with an SJW rant than a scientifically informative video when compared to the “Yanny or Laurel” or “what color is that dress?” videos. 

Secondly, climate change is a highly contested issue, not on whether it is real, but how to address it. Very few informed people believe massive government intervention is the way to tackle the issue, because governments tend towards inefficiency & corruption. The only real government intervention that would work is to add a tax to things that would produce global emissions, such that the market bears the true cost of gasoline & coal use (which is generally unchanged in free market because no individual directly bears the cost), but when you think of implementing such a plan, you will notice how may things can go wrong: What is the right tax to make the market bear the cost of global warming?; Would the government actually use the money to fix the emissions?; How would you prevent corruption in making these decisions?; What items should this include (cigarettes, BBQ, electric plants, matches, gasoline, etc)?; Government lobbying effect in making these decisions?; Etc. 

Additionally, many of these issues tend to be solved by technology & time in an non-government enforced market, as can be seen by synthetic beef, electric cars, nuclear energy, etc. when compared to government interventions (any previous government intervention you can point to). 

Lastly, here’s some videos to watch before you claim it’s an issue that needs to be addressed ASAP (especially by heavy handed government policies), as it’s important to be informed of both sides of the issue before you make a decision:

@Steinchen drei von und zu vierzig 
You won't check my math but you know it's wildly inconclusive?
Right...

Well I did recheck my math and I discovered I did convert PPM to percentages correctly human tech and industry contribute about 1ppm annually since 2014. I also was able to work out how much volume 10,000,000,000 metric tons of CO2 looks like. The diameter of the sphere of all our tech and industries CO2 is about 21.8km. Human existence alone (globally) generates another completely different sphere of CO2 that is about 20km in diameter and is made up of our exhaled breath alone (assuming a whopping 0% of it gets absorbed into anything in the environment over a full year). So 7 billion humans just existing on this planet alone generates almost 1ppm by itself without any tech or industrial activity at all!

So yes after several days of toiling over the math it looks like it was right and all human activity including breathing contributes less than the equivalent of 2ppm to the current CO2 concentration levels. According to every source I provided CO2 doesn't live that long in the atmosphere. It's life is so short that on average most people in developed countries will live through 2 complete CO2 lifecycles. CO2 stays in the atmosphere for 30 years so if you are sixty any CO2 pumped into the air the day you were born completed its lifecycle on your thirtieth birthday and again any CO2 contributions on your thirtieth birthday completed its lifecycle on your sixtieth birthday.

The reality is that any CO2 we add to the atmosphere rolls off every 30 years so by 2044 even if humans increase our CO2 emissions by 100% the net gain in the atmosphere will be equivalent to less than 2ppm per year.

Meaning as a species we'll have to pump out 20 billion metric tons of CO2 (oh and 20 billion metric tons is the same amount as 20,000 million metric tons) to add still barely anything to the environment.

*AS PER USUAL NONE OF THIS MEANS I ADORE CO2 EMISSIONS OR DO NOT THINK THEY ARE A PROBLEM!*

I'm simply saying you are a moron for thinking that CO2 is driving climate change.

Since when does a low concentration of something guarantee a small effect? Last time I checked many toxins are lethal, even in tiny concentrations. So what makes you think a few ppm won't have a significant effect on earth's climate?


And what's with that _"humans would need to pump out over 1,850 times the CO2 from 2014 to 2018 to even close in on the majority of that 411ppm"?_ You _do_ know that there has always been CO2 in the atmosphere, right? It just used to be in a lower concentration. Humans aren't the only cause for CO2, they just contribute an unhealthy amount. There's plenty of natural sources of CO2. 


And yes, in such a carefully balanced system, like earth, a tiny change in the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere can have a drastic effect. If only a tiny fraction of the heat from the sun gets absorbed instead of reflected into space, that definitely has an effect on global temperatures. *1ppm*

Check my math:

5460/5,100,000,000=0.0000010705

If we round up we still get just 1ppm. Now remember that only 0.4% of the 5.1 billion km^3 of atmosphere is CO2 so 5460 km^3 is really a drop in the ocean so where are the other 410ppm of CO2 coming from?

According to this new math and a hopefully more accurate estimate of the approximate volume of the atmosphere from MIT (here: http://web.mit.edu/8.01t/www/materials/ProblemSets/Raw/editedf06PRS/PRS_exam01_combination_sol.doc )

Ehh, no.... Exon scientists were not the first, or novel in the way the authors of the video say they are.

 Arvid Högbom, could be considered one of the first, and he made his discoverys in the late 1800s.  Thomas Chrowder Chamberlin also advocated for the carbon dioxide hypothesis. Wrote a book called "An Attempt to Frame a Working Hypothesis of the Cause of Glacial Periods on an Atmospheric Basis". It was also proven around that time different chemicals, including Co2, does cause a warming effect. Svante Arrhenius first calculated the extent we would warm, before the turn of the century. Hans Suess in 1955 did a analysis and discovered that the co2 levels were being effected in the air, by oil companies. In 1960, Charles David Keeling did actually prove that co2 was rising, and we were on a path to warming. Syukuro Manabe and Richard Wetherald also, after keeling, made a calculation of HOW much the climate would change, giving the current path.

I know this is just a little semantics, and was probably cut for sake a brevity. But its important I feel that people don't get the idea all this was started in the last 50 years; we've know of this for well over 150 years. I think the author intended this to only a segway to the topic of the modern attention of the masses. But still, misinformation is misinformation. Oil companies DID NOT discover climate change, at all. They discovered certain effects, gathered from theories well established before them.

I find it amazing that those on the left can see how a bad actor can manipulate 'science' for their own benefit and yet are completely incapable of seeing how a government or renewable industries can manipulate 'science' for its own benefit as well. 


What they were doing was not saying they should hide the previous science for their own gain. They were saying (as are 'deniers' of today) that there isn't significant enough evidence to come to a drastic conclusion. 


To digress quickly, the use of the term 'denier' in regard to the study of climate and potential anthropogenic effects is extremely alarming. It shows that the issue has moved from being a scientific question to a political dogma nearing a point of becoming a religion in and of itself. Any scientific question should be able to be studied. Those who study them are not 'deniers' for straying from the manufactured narrative. They are scientists doing what scientists are supposed to do. 


Secondly the idea of consensus on the issue of climate change is laughable. It is a shining example of pseudo science/statistics coupled with the stupidity and danger of mass group think. The studies that show scientific consensus are a blatant distortion of the truth so great that the content can be called a lie. The Cook et Al study that is endlessly repeated by every liberal media platform is a joke that is most often used to prove consensus. 
1st. It analyzed only the abstracts of thousands of scientific papers that contained the terms "Global Warming" or "Global Climate Change". If a scientific paper was written to study a particular phenomenon, (lets say the impact of solar radiation and the stripping of 'light' atomic particles from the ionosphere and mesosphere) this study would have an impact on the concept of 'global warming', but there is no reason for the scientist to reference it in his abstract.
Furthermore, the study included papers that imply anthropogenic causes of warming but do not test that hypothesis. These studies could include potential mitigation strategies, opinions, etc. 
A scientist saying he/she implicitly agrees with a concept without testing or questioning said concept cannot be regarded as a reliable source for the validity of the original concept. 


2nd. The study lumps together people who say humans are the chief cause of warming with those who merely mention factors that are in some way responsible for warming to some extent. Effectivly, if a paper mentions anything related to climate that the editors of the study can tie back to human caused warming, it is counted as a 'yes' vote even if it did not pick one way or another. 


3rd. (this is the most damming) If the study stated that there wasn't sufficient evidence to support the catastrophic warming hypotheses, the study was thrown out and not counted as a part of the 97% in any way. 66% of the eleven thousand studies referenced specifically stated that there was not sufficient evidence one way or another and was disregarded entirely. 






Next, about Exxon building offshore oil platforms higher up to prepare for rising sea levels. If you genuinely believe this you seem to be an incompetent buffoon or too lazy to google how any oil platform works. The new oil rigs used (just like the one shown in the video) today aren't tied to the sea floor. Changes in sea level do not affect them in any way. They float.




As far as paying sceinists to promote 'fake science', they may very well have done that. The liberal billionares like Tom Steyer who have fortunes from the new green political movement have the same incentives Exxon did and are just as likely to be corrupt.

https://judithcurry.com/2016/04/17/the-paradox-of-the-climate-change-consensus/

There is genuine scientific consensus on the following points:

global temperatures have increased overall since 1880

humans are contributing to a rise in atmospheric CO2 concentrations

CO2 emits and absorbs infrared radiation

*For the most consequential issues, there remains considerable debate:*

*whether the warming since 1950 has been dominated by human causes*

*how much the planet will warm in the 21st century*

*whether warming is ‘dangerous’*

*whether radically reducing CO2 emissions will improve the climate and human well being*

Leveraged by the consensus on the three points above that are not disputed, the climate ‘consensus’ is being sold as applying to all of the above, even the issues for which there remains considerable debate.

For past a certain point, each increase in the level of consensus makes it more difficult for new information to surface, thereby lowering the veracity we should assign to it.

The skewed scientific  ‘consensus’ does indeed act to reinforce itself, through a range of professional incentives:  ease of publishing results, particularly in high impact journals; success in funding; recognition from peers in terms of awards, promotions, etc.; media attention and publicity for research;  appeal of the simplistic narrative that climate science can ‘save the world’; and a seat at the big policy tables.

The net result of this skewed ‘consensus’ is that inadequate attention is being paid to natural climate variability, and too many people, including scientists, assume that CO2 is a giant control knob that, if reduced, can eliminate bad weather, sea level rise, etc.

While not always clear why the K/C ratio can become highly skewed, one interpretation is that more than just the search for knowledge is at play.

Apart from the professional incentives described above, there are a range of political drivers that incentivize the consensus, including broad environmentalism, anti-fossil fuel sentiments, anti-capitalism sentiments, and a desire for world government that transcends national policies.

@Rick TD Sorry Rick, but guess who is an Environmental Scientist? Me.... (Who's been to the Arctic, and studied the Antarctic for years).

I can assure you that no, nowhere is gaining massive amounts of ice, especially not in Greenland. Antarctica is complicated, but yes, still melting. 

Due to oceanic circulations, warm water penetrates the Arctic easily, which helps raise the Arctic air temperature (along with the loss of the albedo in the Arctic region). This can mean that the air temperature in winter can be upto 20C above normal. Sea ice is the most obvious thing gone in the Arctic - shipping through the Arctic ocean was not possible until recently, but tbh the loss of sea ice not something to be most concerned about anyway. Mainly its ice sheets - they will contribute to sea level rise etc.

For Antarctica, check out the work by Edwards et al (2019) who explain the complicated nature of the Antarctic really well. Basically the Antarctic has a few factors affecting change there. Firstly, the ozone layer has been stuck over Antarctica and thus insulating less heat. Secondly, it doesn't have the same oceanic circulation as the Arctic does (hence its usually colder on average than the Arctic). 

The areas that matter however, the ice sheets in Antarctica, are still melting. Particularly in the West Antarctic ice sheet.

Good video, what about the argument that the consensus of the 97 percent of climate scientists that climate change is caused by man is a lie? The evidence that I've seen to back this up is in the John Cook study (where everyone gets the 97 percent of scientific consensus on climate change). They(John Cook study) omitted the other published scientists who had no conclusion and instead just took the remainder scientists who either agreed or disagreed and that's how we got 97 percent. If you took the rest of the published climate scientists into account then the consensus is 66.4 say they don't have an opinion, 32.6 say we are the cause, and .7 say we are not. Since critical thinking is about examining all the facts no matter if they support or reject your conclusion then why believe in and spread the lie that the debate is settled because it's clearly not. There maybe lots of other factors in climate science that we are missing or maybe it's truly uncontrollable and the weather is going to do whatever it wants based on all the outside influencing factors. However cherry picking facts and reaching the conclusion first and making up evidence to get there is not the way we move forward on this issue.

From 1978 to 1998 the global avg temp of earth increased suddenly by 0.4 degrees C... and then the warming stopped.  The IPCC can't explain the 'pause', and their models do not predict the observed temperatures of the last 40 years, and their warnings are based on the models.  The IPCC is engaged in climate speculation.

"Global Warming" was rebranded "Climate Change"...  because the climate has been changing every moment of every day for billions of years, in extreme ways, and always will.

The correlation between CO2 and temperature seemed promising from 1978 to 1998, but historically its transient at best.  The Roman Warm Period (250BC-400AD) and Medieval Warm Period (950AD-1250AD) both occurred during periods of lower levels of CO2, and well before humans began harnessing and burning hydrocarbons to enhance their lives.

The global warming theories fell apart by 2006,  but investment in the $climate $industry that began with tax payer funding has continued to grow on a massive scale.
https://www.tesla.com/models

CO2 occurs naturally and is emitted continually by oceans (70% of the surface of the planet), volcanoes, decaying plant life, and breathing animals.  Each human adds about 800 pounds of CO2 into the atmosphere each year just by breathing.

CO2 has a well known property where it's greenhouse effect rapidly diminishes as more is added to the atmosphere.  The next molecule of CO2 has less heat retention qualities than the previous.

CO2 is a minuscule part of the atmosphere.  Only 4 molecules out of every ten thousand molecules of atmosphere are CO2.  150 years ago, before human industrialization, it was 3 out of ten thousand.  In other words, after 150 years of hydrocarbon (fossil) fueled industrialization, plus all the CO2 emitted naturally, there is one extra CO2 molecule out of every ten thousand.

CO2 is essential for life, its not a pollutant.  If the level dropped below 1.5 CO2 molecules per ten thousand atmosphere, plant life would struggle to survive.  In fact more CO2 might be a blessing in the fight against world hunger... CO2 is plant food.  The planet is a little greener today than 100 years ago due to a little extra CO2.

The current level of CO2 is 400ppm (parts per million, or 4 parts per ten thousand).  NASA considers a space station safe with levels up to 3000ppm to 5000ppm.  Submarines are considered safe up to 5000ppm to 8000ppm.

Arctic ice is melting, but only represents 1% of the planet's ice.  The Antarctic and Greenland hold the other 99%  (90% and 9% respectively), and both have seen their ice increase significantly over the course of the last 100 years.  They build research centers in the Antarctic on jacks so they can raise them up each year to keep up with the ice/snow accumulation.  Here's a story about a plane (Glacier Girl) that made an emergency landing on Greenland in 1942 and was discovered under 270 feet of ice in 1992... after 50 years of post war hydrocarbon fueled industrialization.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glacier_Girl

We could go on and on, but basically the planet stopped warming,  the climate models don't predict observed climate, the climate warnings are based on the models, and there is a great deal of historical evidence of warmer periods with lower levels of CO2 well before humans began burning hydrocarbons.

It's all a bunch of speculation.  In the early seventies, scientists were speculating on the coming Ice Age.

Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas by far.

The earth's massive water system and the Sun likely play far more significant roles in the natural variability of climate.  The idea that the tiny bit of CO2 in the atmosphere as the 'primary forcing agent' driving temperature and climate is simply not supported by objective science.  Not even close.

To be sure, the $climate $industry is $massive. The banks trade $hundreds of $billions of $dollars of carbon futures every year.  Those banks donate $hundreds of $millions to the cause.  It's great for Tesla shareholders, and of course Al Gore made a fortune promoting it.  The $climate $industry is generating a great deal of wealth.

It's also uncaring. The cost of energy drives the cost of food, clothing, housing (protection from climate), healthcare, transportation, education and every other aspect of modern life.

The regressive climate policies and carbon taxes of the rich continue to keep the 2 to 3 Billion of the poorest people on the planet the poorest people on the planet.  They are poor because the most basic form of wealth is access to energy.  It is energy that has allowed humans to thrive.  

1 to 1.5 billion humans only have access to biomass energy (wood, cow dung), and another 1 to 1.5 billion have no regular access to energy... in total roughly 8 times the population of the United States.

If you don't believe any of this, that's wonderful, you're a skeptic.  Do the research, its at your fingertips.  If you haven't looked into the facts yet you believe, that's faith not science.

Here’s an example of an effect of climate change:
The southern pine beetle is one of the most destructive insects in America. They kill millions of trees per year and cost the logging industry $43 million annually. They’re population is highest during the summer months and lowest during winter months since they’re killed off by the cold. Since the climate is warming, less and less beetles are dying in winter so they’re population is increasing at a huge rate as they’re able to move further north and therefore are causing huge amounts of destruction. The dead trees left behind significantly increase the chance of wildfires and they’re damage.

Even if we try to reduce emissions, worldwide, there are still a lot of systems that cannot run at current rates from non-fossil fuel sources. I think a question we should be asking is how do we get that CO2 out of the air. Basically how can we tilt the Carbon cycle towards pulling CO2 from the air. If we can do that, and then also find a way to turn that captured CO2 back to a fuel, we could potentially control the amount of CO2 and balance it with what we use.

Green energy is great, but it is just not cost efficient enough to be realistic. If we can't completely go green, we really do need to start looking into and building thorium reactors. From what I can find, thorium is more abundant than uranium and has a shorter half-life in general. It may not be renewable, but it will drastically slow down the CO2 output if we really ramp up plant building and usage.

I think that the Earth is warming, and I think that it is caused by humans. However, our assessment of its impact has been deeply flawed. Lookup how climate change is supposed to affect precipitation in your area. It varies a great deal as heat leads  to desertification but also rainfall, and you can't have a desert if there's rain. How about crop yield? Increased temps increase oxygen fixation in C3 plants but increased CO2 yields greater crop yield. The only more certain negative affect is rising sea levels which can be dealt with decades at a time, excluding river flooding. Overall, we expect 2100 to be 4 degrees C warmer, so for me that's roughly -16 in the winter months and +34 in the warmer months and isn't a substantial change as everyone forecasts. Shifting the mean does make fringe events significantly more common, I'm not ignorant of this, but to think that it's going to be this devastating Armageddon seems ignorant at how good life is at surviving much much much worst than 4 degrees shift in the mean.

Academic scientists, many of them also science fiction and science essay authors, suspected this as far back as the 1940s.  Isaac Asimov mentioned it in science fact essays during the 1950s and 1960s, and used a sociopolitical analogy to the climate change problems we face as part of the plot of his novel “The Gods Themselves.”

Also, in one of his mystery stories in the Black Widowers Club series, the answer to the mystery involved a young boy from Quebec, who was a French history fanatic, describing an Exxon station as the sign of the Cross of Lorraine.  This was during the oil crisis of the 1970s, when a common nickname for Exxon was the “sign of the double cross.”

@DeadlyMargiKarp223 I wasn't going to respond, but this will be the last one. I promise.

We can't send each other links back & forth if neither of us trusts the source.
I don't trust your sources, you wouldn't trust mine. So “providing evidence” that you are requesting is a useless endeavor.

So, we can really only communicate on a common-sense level.

I've provided No "science denial", as there has been no scientific methodology used here. If NASA could recreate a planet (with all the same factors Earth has.. Volcanoes, Sunlight, Moonlight, Solar Flares, Oceans, Wind, Geology, Plant & Animal life, etc..) and adjust the CO2 levels for testing their theories, this would be an application of the Scientific Method. But they can't... so by definition, until they do, the Scientific Method cannot be used here. Only Pseudoscience can be used.

Forget the fact that they only used 1 model which was mathematically wrong, and not corrected.. Let's pretend it was correct.

By only using 1 variable (C02 "Plant Food"), and omitting factors like the giant fusion reactor in the sky! There's no way to determine if their conclusions are correct.

But by using this same methodology, I can conclude that Ice Cream Sales cause more Shark Attacks.
A completely true statement if you're only looking at those 2 factors. (Several studies have been done to prove this!) However, it omits all other factors.

Correlation does not always equal causation.

And no, this is not a straw man argument. It's simply using the same methodology Climate Change Proponents have used.

Climate is ALWAYS changing. No one denies that. We had an Ice Age, now we don't. It obviously changes. 

The question is.. do we trust these agencies that have lied to us already, about an "imminent danger" we cannot use any of our senses or accurate models to verify?

And if we do trust them, do we believe them capable of fixing it?

To both, my conclusion is No. Yours might be yes!

If you want to buy a solar car, or panels for your home to play it safe. That's reasonable and responsible of you to do.

Climate change is real, humans are contributors, sure, the thing is, CO2 is only one factor. 66% of scientists don't point humans as the reason of climate change, they stay neutral and 33% do blame humans, the rest say no or not sure, which is the 1% We need to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, but even then, global warming would probably still happen. There's been radical climate changes before humans and sea levels rises as well. The reality is we still don't understand climate as well as we think we do. Other than CO2, another green house gas is vaporized water and we can't even predict how clouds form, heck, we can't even predict the weather within a 10 day span. From 1800 to now, the global temperature rose 1 celcius degree and the sea levels rose at an average of 9 inches. 12,800 years ago, at the end of the Younger Dryas, average temperatures rose 10 celsius degrees in a span of 10 years, more than a 100 times faster than the one we've experienced in the last 140 years. Scientists still don't understand why this happened. Over the past 500 million years, sea levels have gone up and down dramatically (as much as 700 feet higher than today, other times 100 feet lower). My point is, the data we have shows correlation but doesn't actually suggest CO2 is what's causing the temperature to rise, it does create a lot of pollution which is killing millions of people every year though. Don't lose hope, keep fighting to reduce fossil fuel pollution, keep fighting to make a switch to renewable energy, but that might not fix the problem, only slow it down. Remember, predictions have been wrong in the past and more when it comes to climate, a subject we don't understand clearly yet.

The greenhouse effect was discovered in the mid-1800s. (It explains why the Earth isn't frozen over.) In 1957 a Bell Telephone tv science special on the weather mentioned that growing use of fossil fuels would lead to global warming. I first became interested in the subject as a physics major at the start of the 1970s. (And contrary to common belief, the possibility of global cooling was a short-lived minority concern among climate scientists in the 70s, not a widely accepted one.) The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change was created during the Reagan administration. In short, Exxon scientists didn't discover climate change, they just verified what was already known. @DeadlyMargiKarp223 wow. You are too stupid to even argue with so i'll explain a few things to any late coming observers to help contain that stupidity to you. 

I've not even stated my position on Catastrophic Anthropogenic Global Climate Change... I stated that "denier" is green for "heretic".

An ad hominem attack is where, rather than attack the arguments of one's opponent they attack the person... works in court (regretfully) but science is about logos, not ethos... so when I say i'm not going to read articles posted without valid arguments by a pokemon fanatic, I AM committing an ad hominem attack because i'm attempting to discredit my opponent by the implication that his pokemon fetish (which is an attribute evidenced by his name) discredits him making his statements invalid... when logic dictates that what he says, not who he is, is what makes his arguments invalid. Whether the attribute cited in an ad hominem attack is true is irrelevant to whether it's fallacious. As a side, the reason i'm not following his links is because unless it's attached to an argument I've not heard, odds are, reading the link he took 10 seconds to cut and paste would be 10 to 20 minutes of reading to see nothing new, because I have done research. 

In addition to not understanding jack about what the ad hominem attack, he also proves his lack of fluency in logic when he accuses me of executing the fallacy fallacy as he describes it as identifying a fallacy when there is none... the fallacy fallacy has nothing to do with being wrong... it simply states that someone using a fallacy isn't proof that their conclusion is wrong. For example, if I use a non sequitur to determine margikarp a leftist, my logic is fallacious, but my statement that he is politically left may still be true. 

This has been a lesson in logic, the foundation of the scientific process.  :)

Carbon Dioxide is "the fourth-most abundant compound in the atmosphere" and "Currently at levels of Over 0.04 percent (400 PPM)." YES... 
But guess what?!  That's ALMOST TWICE it's NATURAL MAXIMUM Prior to The Industrial Revolution in the 1800's.

The Earth goes through glacial periods of cooling, then interglacial warming periods, regularly following the natural deviations in the Earth's Tilt.  These are known as Milankovitch Cycles.  We SHOULD BE IN A COOLING PERIOD RIGHT NOW... But Guess What, We F#@%ED it UP with our Burning of Fossil-Fuels for Hundreds of Years which we've ONLY Exponentially INCREASED Our Burning Rates For.

Prior to the Industrial Revolution, Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide Levels naturally deviated (Alongside corresponding Milankovitch Cycles) in the last Million Years from Between 0.017% (117 PPM) to about a Normal Maximum of 0.028% (228 PPM) (only reaching a Natural 0.03% (300 PPM) ONCE, Briefly, in the last MILLION YEARS), and the last time the Earth's Atmospheric C02 Levels were As HIGH As They Are Now was OVER 3 MILLION YEARS AGO, when temperature was 2°–3°C (3.6°–5.4°F) higher than during the pre-industrial era, and sea level was 15–25 meters (50–80 feet) higher than today.

It is a Scientific Observational FACT that Atmospheric C02 Level increases CORRESPOND with a Followed Atmospheric Global TEMPERATURE Increase.
And it is a Scientific Observational FACT that our Reliance On Fossil Fuels for industry, electricity, and transportation Has EXPONENTIALLY Increased Atmospheric CO2.

Fossil fuels like coal and oil contain carbon that plants pulled out of the atmosphere through photosynthesis over the span of Many Millions of years; we are returning that carbon to the atmosphere in just a few Hundred years. The annual rate of increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide over the past 60 years is about 100 times faster than previous natural increases, such as those that occurred at the end of the last ice age 11,000-17,000 years ago.

Glacial Periods of the Milankovitch Cycle Naturally last around about 90,000 years.  And a full change in the Earth's Natural Tilt takes about 40,000 years.  Guess what, The Earth already Finished Reaching it's Nearest (Warmest) Tilt about 10,000 years ago and is Now in the process of it's 40,000 year tilting Away From the Sun and COOLING. So, AGAIN, the EARTH SHOULD BE COOLING WITH DROPPING C02 LEVELS...  BUT NOOOOOOOOOO, IT'S NOT, C02 Levels are ACTUALLY STILL INCREASING AND The Earth is HEATING UP!!

A Good Analogy here... is that it's a bit like...  Putting some Ice-Cream in the Freezer...  Only to open the Freezer Later to find that the Ice-Cream Has Caught On FIRE.

I'm not sure where you pulled those numbers from, but Greater Than 0.01% (Which is Actually the Approximate Current Difference between it's Naturally-Occurring Average Maximum) IS MUCH MUCH Greater than 0.0016%.  Maybe the source you got that number from was referring ONLY to What Humans Themselves BREATHE OUT, Rather than What We BURN INTO THE AIR???

Co2, which is blamed for climate warming, has only a volume share of 0.04% . And of these 0.04%  CO2, 95%  come from natural sources, such as volcanoes or decomposition processes in nature. The human  content in the air is thus only 0.0016% .

While I support your message, this is not great evidence of climate change. A single year, or even five or ten years, of anomalous behavior isn't unusual. Climate change does not happen on the scale of decades, though it is accelerating.

The reason this kind of evidence is unhelpful isn't because it doesn't support climate change, it's because it suggests that local evidence - taken over a short time period - of a global event which takes place over many years is valid evidence. Basically it means that you saying "this year we had weird weather in this part of the world" is just as valid as me saying "this year we had very normal weather in this part of the world." It's part of what lets climate change deniers do stupid things like take a snowball into the US Congress as "evidence" that climate change isn't real.

This is from a Debate I had with a Liberal about Anthropogenic Global Warming AKA Man-Made Climate Change...

"So your argument is that mankind makes up the overwhelming majority of global warming. Now there are many different fact-based counter-arguments I could use to explain why that’s wrong. I could explain how the climate has always been going through massive changes since the Earth’s very creation billions of years ago. I could further elaborate on that point by explaining how in just the past two thousand years we have seen the “Roman Warm Period” which lasted from roughly 250 BC to 400 AD, and was even hotter than it is today. Followed by the “Cooler Dark Ages” which lasted from roughly 450 – 900 AD. Which was then followed by the “Medieval Warm Period” which lasted from roughly 950 - 1250 AD and was at least as warm as today. Which was next followed by the “Little Ice Age” which lasted from roughly 1300 – 1850 AD. After that was another Warming Trend which we are currently in right now. It is generally agreed on by all scientists that before the 1960’s there is no way that CO2 emissions were sufficient enough to play a part in climate change. However, the current warming period started around the 1850’s roughly a century before humans could start playing any significant part in it. This would be an entirely fact-based argument.

Or instead of that counter-argument I could simply point out that right now Jupiter, Mars, Saturn, Neptune and Pluto are also going through a warming period. Astronomers found this out by measuring the ice on those planets (Pluto isn’t technically a Planet anymore but that’s just semantics). That would also be an entirely fact-based argument.

However, the argument I would like to focus on is one that’s a little more simple yet still fairly indisputable. Your entire belief relies on mankind's CO2 emission being the primary factor in global warming. This is the entire core of your belief and if it is proven wrong then your entire beliefs about global warming are false. So let me ask you something. Do you know why climate change alarmists were so big on using the term “global warming” in the 90’s but shortly after the beginning of the 2000’s they quickly decided to switch to the term “climate change”. This was actually pretty simple. The reason why is cause global warming STOPPED. That’s right, around the beginning of the 2000’s the climate stopped warming and has remained flat since then. We are nearing two decades now with no change in the temperature of the climate. So maybe right now you're thinking “oh well, humans must have lowered their CO2 emissions”. And if that’s what you’re thinking then you are dead wrong. In fact it’s quite the opposite. Mankind is actually expending more CO2 emissions than ever before. In fact about 25% of all CO2 emissions from all of humanity have occurred during this period of no net warming.

So here’s the deal, your belief is that mankind is the primary factor that contributes to the warming of the climate and the primary way they do this is through CO2 emissions. Your belief requires that the more CO2 emissions humanity is expending, the warmer the climate gets. This is the very core of your belief and it’s critical that it be true or your beliefs are just flat-out wrong. This is not some trivial detail for your belief, this is make-or-break. Now the facts make it very clear that humanity is expending far, far more CO2 emissions than ever before and the climate is not warming. This means that your beliefs and the facts are incompatible. They cannot both be true, it is simply a logical contradiction. You have to choose what has more credibility to you. Your ideological beliefs or the facts. I choose to believe the facts over any of my ideological beliefs. If a fact proves my ideological beliefs wrong then my ideological beliefs adjust or change entirely. Now you have to choose whether or not you will ignore the facts so that your ideological beliefs do not have to adjust or change for them. To be completely honest I don’t think you will. I think you will do exactly as I have said liberals do. You will ignore the facts as soon as they become inconvenient for your ideology. Just as you ignored all the facts about Justin Cooks fraudulence earlier. Generally speaking, you guys hold such blind, irrational faith in AGW that it is comparable to a religion for you guys. For most of you, there is no amount a facts in the world that can deter you from this near-religious faith in AGW. I hope you are an exception but I sincerely doubt it..."

@steve A few problems with that:

1) We don't have enough nuclear plants to produce 60% of the energy needs and we don't have a decade to spend on their construction even if we did.  By comparison a solar farm can be built in a year (or less).  To meet 60% of world energy needs we'd need to construct another 2000 nuclear plants and the associated mines and waste storage facilities.  That's never going to happen, especially not in the decade we have to do something about this.

2)  A nuclear plant is useful for about 50 years.  After that the plant has to be decommissioned.  So what are you going to do in 50 years when, in your plan, 60% of the world's energy production disappears?  You're going to have to be continuously building new plants.

3)  Molten salt tanks can store energy for about a week at a time and require much less land area than you suggest.  Tanks that power a 100-megawatt turbine for four hours would be about 9 m (30 ft) tall and 24 m (80 ft) in diameter.  So if we're assuming we need it for say 12 hrs a day that means it would be 27 m tall and 72 m in diameter.  Quite a bit less than a coal plant requires.

If we're going to store power for 12 hours at a time and require 100,000 TWh of storage we'd need to reserve about 4500 acres for storage.  That's less than 10 square miles across the entire planet!  Add that to the 2% of the Earth's surface we'd need to cover with solar panels to produce 200,000 TWh of electricity and you still have 2% of the Earth's surface.  And that's with the comparatively low efficiency of our current solar panels.

What you all seem to be forgetting is that we all share a massive fusion reactor.  We don't need to produce more fission reactors when we can get the energy that is already being produced.  More of the sun’s energy strikes the Earth’s surface in two hours than we consume in all forms every year.  Why are we not using it?

"also, the pricing is completely disconnected from the reality. an energy source that doesn’t work 80% of the time might be cheap (per kwh produced), but you still have to pay (and provide) for the power when it’s not working"

Climate change will very likely result in a huge blow to biodiversity. Remember how much of a problem it is if the bees all die? Imagine that, but with many, many more species, all over the world. Weather will worsen, catastrophic wildfires and hurricanes become the norm, as do polar vortexes. Areas afflicted by drought may end up experiencing even less rainfall, or rarely get so much as to cause frequent flooding. Maintaining the current level of resource production: food, water, energy, etc. becomes more and more difficult, let alone expansion to accommodate moving and growing populations.

Etan Chamare To briefly name some issues not already stated: decreased biodiversity (6th mass extinction), run away greenhouse effect (look up Venus), lower crop yields, air pollution, water pollution, ocean acidification, acid rain, worse weather (hurricanes, droughts, rains, heatwaves, etc), less drinkable water, etc. I’m sure there’s more besides these and those already named but these are all that I could think of off the top of my head.

The key here is a gradual reduction in our reliance on fossil fuels. We are producing tones of carbon emissions and as we fill the atmosphere with these gases, the climate will rise. A good example is Venus, the hottest planet in the solar system. It’s not so hot just because it’s closer to the sun but also because the atmosphere is made up of mostly Sulfuric gases, which are greenhouse gases. You say it’s 1 degree per century but that doesn’t account for the rapid acceleration of the temperature. As we release more gases, our average temperatures will rise faster and faster world-wide. When the polar ice caps melt, sea levels will rise. In roughly 50 years I believe at this rate, most (if not all) of Long Island will be underwater. I live in California and back during the tsunami that caused the Fukushima disaster we saw major changes on our beaches; the shore line rose significantly. One beach I visited was completely submerged and the only thing that prevented the ocean from covering the roads was a stone wall about 2ft high. Our planet can heal itself though. Planting more trees and flowers while decreasing emissions will result in the gradual decline of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. We don’t have to ban gas cars, but rather stop using gasoline and coal for electricity. We could build dams for hydroelectric power in existing rivers, we can build windmills and solar panel farms to harness more natural energy, and most of all we could build more nuclear power plants. We talk about how dangerous they are but let’s look at the two most notable nuclear disasters: Chernobyl and Fukushima. The Chernobyl meltdown was simply caused by complacency; when the reactor first showed signs of instability they didn’t shut it down. Fukushima was unavoidable due to tsunamis that hit Japan in 2015. So what we do is build power plants inland, away from areas with frequent natural disasters and have strict regulations on operations. This way, chances are slim-to-none that another disaster will occur. And if we do this gradually, we can easily transfer from a fossil fuel reliant society to a nuclear powered society with no damage to the economy ore environment.
